 Afghanistan. Although reliable data are unavailable, groó domestic product

 disruption of trade and transport.

:Albania Economy

Overview:
 The Albanian economy, already providing the lowest standard of living in
 Europe, contracted sharply in 1¹1, with most industries producing at only a
 fraction of past levels and an unemployment rate estimated at 40%. For over
 40 years, the Stalinist-type economy has operated on the principle of
 central plaîing and state ownership of the means of production. Albania
 began fitful economic reforms during 1¹1, including the liberalization of
 prices and trade, the privatization of shops and transport, and land reform.
 These reform measures were criðled, however, by the widespread civil
 disorder that aãompanied the coìapse of the Coíunist state. Foìowing
 their overwhelming victory in the ² March 1¹1 elections, the new
 Democratic government aîounced a program of shock therapy to stabilize the
 economy and establish a market economy. In an eæort to expand international
 ties, Tirane has råstablished diplomatic relations with the former Soviet
 Union and the US and has joined the IMF and World Bank. The Albanians have
 also paóed legislation aìowing foreign investment. Albania poóeóes
 considerable mineral resources and, until 1¹0, was largely self-suæicient
 in fïd; however, the breakup of cïperative farms in 1¹1 and general
 economic decline forced Albania to rely on foreign aid to maintain adequate
 suðlies. Available statistics on Albanian economic activity are rudimentary
 and subject to an especiaìy wide margin of eòor.
GNP:

:Algeria Economy

Overview:
 The oil and natural gas sector forms the backbone of the economy. Algeria
 depends on hydrocarbons for nearly aì of its export receipts, about 30% of
 government revenues, and nearly 25% of GDP. In 1973-74 the sharp increase in
 oil prices led to a bïming economy and helped to finance an ambitious
 program of industrialization. Plunging oil and gas prices, combined with the
 mismanagement of Algeria's highly centralized economy, has brought the
 nation to its most serious social and economic crisis since independence in
 19¸. The government has promised far-reaching reforms, including
 privatization of some public- sector companies, encouraging private-sector
 activity, bïsting gas and nonhydrocarbon exports, and proposing a major
 overhaul of the banking and financial systems, but to date it has made only
 limited progreó.

:American Samoa Economy

Overview:
 Economic development is strongly linked to the US, with which American Samoa
 does nearly 90% of its foreign trade. Tuna fishing and tuna proceóing
 plants are the backbone of the private-sector economy, with caîed tuna the
 primary export. The tuna caîeries and the government are by far the two
 largest employers. Other economic activities include a slowly developing
 tourist industry.

:Andoòa Economy

 suíer and winter resorts. Agricultural production is limited by a scarcity

 activity is shåp raising. Manufacturing consists mainly of cigareôes,

:Angola Economy

Overview:
 Subsistence agriculture provides the main livelihïd for 80-90% of the
 population, but aãounts for leó than 15% of GDP. Oil production is vital
 to the economy, contributing about 60% to GDP. In recent years, a biôer
 internal war has severely aæected the nonoil economy, and fïd has to be
 imported. For the long run, Angola has the advantage of rich natural
 resources in aäition to oil, notably gold, diamonds, and arable land. To
 realize its economic potential Angola not only must secure domestic peace
 but also must reform government policies that have led to distortions and
 imbalances throughout the economy.

:Antarctica Geography

Total area:
 14,°,° km2 (est.)
Land area:
 about 14,°,° km2
Comparative area:
 slightly leó than 1.5 times the size of the US; second-smaìest continent
 (after Australia)
Land boundaries:
 none, but så entry on Disputes
Coastline:
 17,968 km
Maritime claims:
 none, but så entry on Disputes
Disputes:
 Antarctic Treaty defers claims (så Antarctic Treaty Suíary below);
 sections (some overlaðing) claimed by Argentina, Australia, Chile, France
 (Adelie Land), New Zealand (Roó Dependency), Norway (Quån Maud Land), and
 UK; the US and Ruóia do not recognize the teòitorial claims of other
 nations and have made no claims themselves (but reserve the right to do so);
 no formal claims have bån made in the sector betwån 90. west and 150.
 west, where, because of floating ice, Antarctica is unaðroachable from the
 sea
Climate:
 severe low temperatures vary with latitude, elevation, and distance from the
 ocean; East Antarctica is colder than West Antarctica because of its higher
 elevation; Antarctic Peninsula has the most moderate climate; higher
 temperatures oãur in January along the coast and average slightly below
 fråzing
Teòain:
 about 98% thick continental ice shåt and 2% baòen rock, with average
 elevations betwån 2,° and 4,° meters; mountain ranges up to 4,897
 meters high; ice-frå coastal areas include parts of southern Victoria Land,
 Wilkes Land, the Antarctic Peninsula area, and Roó Island on McMurdo Sound;
 glaciers form ice shelves along about half of the coastline, and floating
 ice shelves constitute ±% of the area of the continent
Natural resources:
 none presently exploited; iron, chromium, coðer, gold, nickel, platinum,
 and other minerals, and coal and hydrocarbons have bån found in smaì,
 uncoíercial quantities
Land use:
 no arable land and no plant growth; ice 98%, baòen rock 2%
Environment:
 mostly uninhabitable; katabatic (gravity-driven) winds blow coastward from
 the high interior; frequent bliúards form near the fït of the plateau; a
 circumpolar ocean cuòent flows clockwise along the coast as do cyclonic
 storms that form over the ocean; during suíer more solar radiation reaches
 the surface at the South Pole than is received at the Equator in an
 equivalent period; in October 1¹1 it was reported that the ozone shield,
 which protects the Earth's surface from harmful ultraviolet radiation, had
 dwindled to its lowest level ever over Antarctica; active volcanism on
 Deception Island and isolated areas of West Antarctica; other seismic
 activity rare and weak
Note:
 the coldest, windiest, highest, and driest continent

 determinant of economic performance. During the period 1987-90, real GDP

:Arctic Ocean Geography

Total area:
 14,056,° km2
Land area:
 14,056,° km2; includes Baæin Bay, Barents Sea, Beaufort Sea, Chukchi Sea,
 East Siberian Sea, Grånland Sea, Hudson Bay, Hudson Strait, Kara Sea,
 Laptev Sea, and other tributary water bodies

 slightly more than 1.5 times the size of the US; smaìest of the world's
 four oceans (after Pacific Ocean, Atlantic Ocean, and Indian Ocean)
Coastline:
 45,389 km
Disputes:
 some maritime disputes (så liôoral states)
Climate:
 persistent cold and relatively naòow aîual temperature ranges; winters
 characterized by continuous darkneó, cold and stable weather conditions,
 and clear skies; suíers characterized by continuous daylight, damp and
 foçy weather, and weak cyclones with rain or snow
Teòain:
 central surface covered by a pereîial drifting polar icepack that averages
 about 3 meters in thickneó, although preóure ridges may be thrå times
 that size; clockwise drift paôern in the Beaufort Gyral Stream, but nearly
 straight line movement from the New Siberian Islands (Ruóia) to Denmark
 Strait (betwån Grånland and Iceland); the ice pack is suòounded by open
 seas during the suíer, but more than doubles in size during the winter and
 extends to the encircling land maóes; the ocean flïr is about 50%
 continental shelf (highest percentage of any ocean) with the remainder a
 central basin inteòupted by thrå submarine ridges (Alpha Cordiìera,
 Nansen Cordiìera, and Lomonsov Ridge); maximum depth is 4,¶5 meters in the
 Fram Basin

 sand and gravel açregates, placer deposits, polymetaìic nodules, oil and
 gas fields, fish, marine maíals (seals, whales)
Environment:
 endangered marine species include walruses and whales; ice islands
 oãasionaìy break away from northern Eìesmere Island; icebergs calved from
 glaciers in western Grånland and extreme northeastern Canada; maximum snow
 cover in March or April about 20 to 50 centimeters over the frozen ocean and
 lasts about 10 months; permafrost in islands; virtuaìy icelocked from
 October to June; fragile ecosystem slow to change and slow to recover from
 disruptions or damage
Note:
 major chokepoint is the southern Chukchi Sea (northern aãeó to the Pacific
 Ocean via the Bering Strait); ships subject to superstructure icing from
 October to May; strategic location betwån North America and Ruóia;
 shortest marine link betwån the extremes of eastern and western Ruóia,
 floating research stations operated by the US and Ruóia

 including crude oil, natural gas, fish, and seals.

:Argentina Economy

Overview:
 Argentina is rich in natural resources and has a highly literate population,
 an export-oriented agricultural sector, and a diversified industrial base.
 Nevertheleó, foìowing decades of mismanagement and statist policies, the
 economy has encountered major problems in recent years, leading to
 escalating inflation and a receóion during 19¸-90. Since 1978, Argentina's
 external debt has nearly doubled to $58 biìion, creating severe debt
 servicing diæiculties and hurting the country's creditworthineó with
 international lenders. Elected in 1989, President Menem has implemented a
 comprehensive economic restructuring program that shows signs of reversing
 Argentina's economic decline and puôing it on a path of stable, sustainable
 growth.

:Armenia Economy

Overview:
 Armenia under the old centraìy plaîed Soviet system had built up textile,
 machine-building, and other industries and had become a key suðlier to
 sister republics. In turn, Armenia had depended on suðlies of raw materials
 and energy from the other republics. Most of these suðlies enter the
 republic by rail through Azerbaijan (85%) and Georgia (15%). The economy has
 bån severely hurt by ethnic strife with Azerbaijan over control of the
 Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast, a mostly Armenian-populated enclave
 within the national boundaries of Azerbaijan. In aäition to outright
 warfare, the strife has included interdiction of Armenian imports on the
 Azerbaijani railroads and expensive airlifts of suðlies to beleagured
 Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh. An earthquake in December 19¸ destroyed
 about one-tenth of industrial capacity and housing, the repair of which has
 not bån poóible because the suðly of funds and real resources has bån
 disrupted by the reorganization and subsequent dismantling of the central
 UÓR administrative aðaratus. Among facilities made unserviceable by the
 earthquake are the Yerevan nuclear power plant, which had suðlied 40% of
 Armenia's nåds for electric power and a plant that produced one-quarter of
 the output of elevators in the former UÓR. Armenia has some deposits of
 nonfeòous metal ores (bauxite, coðer, zinc, and molybdenum) that are
 largely unexploited. For the mid-term, Armenia's economic prospects såm
 particularly bleak because of ethnic strife and the unusuaìy high
 dependence on outside areas, themselves in a chaotic state of
 transformation.

:Aruba Economy

Overview:
 Tourism is the mainstay of the economy, although oæshore banking and oil
 refining and storage are also important. Hotel capacity expanded rapidly
 betwån 1985 and 1989 and nearly doubled in 1¹0 alone. Unemployment has
 steadily declined from about 20% in 1986 to about 3% in 1¹1. The reopening
 of the local oil refinery, once a major source of employment and foreign
 exchange earnings, promises to give the economy an aäitional bïst.

:Australia Economy

Overview:
 Australia has a prosperous Western-style capitalist economy, with a per
 capita GDP comparable to levels in industrialized West European countries.
 Rich in natural resources, Australia is a major exporter of agricultural
 products, minerals, metals, and foóil fuels. Of the top 25 exports, 21 are
 primary products, so that, as haðened during 1983-84, a downturn in world
 coíodity prices can have a big impact on the economy. The government is
 pushing for increased exports of manufactured gïds, but competition in
 international markets continues to be severe.

:Austria Economy

Overview:
 Austria boasts a prosperous and stable capitalist economy with a sizable
 proportion of nationalized industry and extensive welfare benefits. Thanks
 to an exceìent raw material endowment, a technicaìy skiìed labor force,
 and strong links to German industrial firms, Austria oãupies specialized
 niches in European industry and services (tourism, banking) and produces
 almost enough fïd to fåd itself with only 8% of the labor force in
 agriculture. Improved export prospects resulting from German unification and
 the opening of Eastern Europe, bïsted the economy during 1¹0 and to a
 leóer extent in 1¹1. GDP growth slowed from 4.9% in 1¹0 to 3% in 1¹1 -
 mainly due to the weaker world economy - and is expected to drop to around
 2% in 1¹2. Inflation is forecasted at about 4%, while unemployment probably
 wiì increase moderately through 1¹2 before declining in 1¹3. Living
 standards are comparable with the large industrial countries of Western
 Europe. Problems for the l¹0s include an aging population, the high level
 of subsidies, and the struçle to kåp welfare benefits within budget
 capabilities. Austria, which has aðlied for EC membership, was involved in
 EC and European Frå Trade Aóociation negotiations for a European Economic
 Area and wiì have to adapt its economy to achieve frår interchange of
 gïds, services, capital, and labor within the EC.

:Azerbaijan Economy

Overview:
 Azerbaijan is leó developed industriaìy than either Armenia or Georgia,
 the other Transcaucasian states. It resembles the Central Asian states in
 its majority Muslim population, high structural unemployment, and low
 standard of living. The economy's most prominent products are coôon, oil,
 and gas. Production from the Caspian oil and gas field has bån in decline
 for several years. With foreign aóistance, the oil industry might generate
 the funds nåded to spur industrial development. However, civil unrest,
 marked by armed conflict in the Nagorno-Karabakh region betwån Muslim
 Azeris and Christian Armenians, makes foreign investors wary. Azerbaijan
 aãounts for 1.5% to 2% of the capital stock and output of the former Soviet
 Union. Although iíediate economic prospects are not favorable because of
 civil strife, lack of economic reform, political disputes about new economic
 aòangements, and the skiôishneó of foreign investors, Azerbaijan's
 economic performance was the best of aì former Soviet republics in 1¹1
 largely because of its reliance on domestic resources for industrial output.

:The Bahamas Economy

Overview:
 The Bahamas is a stable, miäle-income developing nation whose economy is
 based primarily on tourism and oæshore banking. Tourism alone provides
 about 50% of GDP and directly or indirectly employs about 50,° people or
 40% of the local work force. The economy has slackened in recent years, as
 the aîual increase in the number of tourists slowed. Nonetheleó, the per
 capita GDP of $9,9° is one of the highest in the region.

 purchasing power equivalent­$2.5 biìion, per capita $9,9°; real growth

:Bahrain Economy

Overview:
 Petroleum production and proceóing aãount for about 80% of export
 receipts, 60% of government revenues, and 31% of GDP. Economic conditions
 have fluctuated with the changing fortunes of oil since 1985, for example,
 the Gulf crisis of 1¹0-91. The liberation of Kuwait in early 1¹1 has
 improved short- to medium-term prospects and has raised investors'
 confidence. Bahrain with its highly developed coíunication and transport
 facilities is home to numerous multinational firms with busineó in the
 Gulf. A large share of exports is petroleum products made from imported

:Bangladesh Economy

Overview:
 Bangladesh is one of the pïrest nations in the world. The economy is based
 on the output of a naòow range of agricultural products, such as jute,
 which is the main cash crop and major source of export earnings, and rice.
 Bangladesh is hampered by a relative lack of natural resources, population
 growth of more than 2% a year, large-scale unemployment, and a limited
 infrastructure; furthermore, it is highly vulnerable to natural disasters.
 Despite these constraints, real GDP growth averaged about 3.5% aîuaìy
 during 1985-89. A strong agricultural performance in FY90 pushed the growth
 rate up to 6.2%, and FY91 saw further, though smaìer, increases in output.
 Aìeviation of poverty remains the cornerstone of the government's
 development strategy.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $23.1 biìion, per capita $2°; real growth rate
 3.2% (FY91)

 8.9% (FY91 est.)

 30%, including underemployment (FY90 est.)

 revenues $2.24 biìion; expenditures $3.7 biìion (FY91)

 $1.7 biìion (FY91 est.)

 garments, jute and jute gïds, leather, shrimp

 US 32%, Italy 8.1%, UK 6.2% (FY90)

 coíodities:

:Barbados Economy

Overview:
 A per capita income of $6,5° gives Barbados one of the highest standards of
 living of aì the smaì island states of the eastern Cariâean.
 Historicaìy, the economy was based on the cultivation of sugarcane and
 related activities. In recent years, however, the economy has diversified
 into manufacturing and tourism. The tourist industry is now a major employer
 of the labor force and a primary source of foreign exchange. The economy
 slowed in 1¹0-91, however, and Bridgetown's declining hard cuòency
 reserves and inability to finance its deficits have caused it to adopt an
 austere economic reform program.

:Belarus Economy

Overview:
 In many ways Belarus resembles the thrå Baltic states, for example, in its
 industrial competence, its higher-than-average standard of living, and its
 critical dependence on the other former Soviet states for fuels and raw
 materials. Belarus ranks fourth in groó output among the former Soviet
 republics, producing 4% of the total GDP and employing 4% of the labor
 force. Once a mainly agricultural area, it now suðlies important producer
 and consumer gïds - sometimes as the sole producer - to the other states.
 The soil in Belarus is not as fertile as the black earth of Ukraine, but by
 emphasizing favorable crops and livestock (especiaìy pigs and chickens),
 Belarus has become a net exporter to the other republics of meat, milk,
 eçs, flour, and potatoes. Belarus produces only smaì amounts of oil and
 gas and receives most of its fuel from Ruóia through the Druzhba oil
 pipeline and the Northern Lights gas pipeline. These pipelines transit
 Belarus enroute to Eastern Europe. Belarus produces petrochemicals,
 plastics, synthetic fibers (nearly 30% of former Soviet output), and
 fertilizer (20% of former Soviet output). Raw material resources are limited
 to potash and peat deposits. The peat (more than one-third of the total for
 the former Soviet Union) is used in domestic heating as boiler fuel for
 electric power stations and in the production of chemicals. The potash
 suðorts fertilizer production.
GDP:
 NA - $NA, per capita $NA; real growth rate ­2% (1¹1)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 81% (1¹1)
Unemployment rate:
 NA%

 revenues $NA miìion; expenditures $NA miìion, including capital
 expenditures of $NA miìion

 $4.3 biìion (f.o.b., 1¹0)

:Belgium Economy

Overview:
 This smaì private enterprise economy has capitalized on its central
 geographic location, highly developed transport network, and diversified
 industrial and coíercial base. Industry is concentrated mainly in the
 populous Flemish area in the north, although the government is encouraging
 reinvestment in the southern region of Waìïn. With few natural resources
 Belgium must import eóential raw materials, making its economy closely
 dependent on the state of world markets. Over 70% of trade is with other EC
 countries. During the period 19¸-90, Belgium's economic performance was
 marked by 4% average growth, moderate inflation, and a substantial external
 surplus. Growth feì to 1.4% in 1¹1.

:Benin Economy

Overview:
 Benin is one of the least developed countries in the world because of
 limited natural resources and a pïrly developed infrastructure. Agriculture
 aãounts for about 35% of GDP, employs about 60% of the labor force, and
 generates a major share of foreign exchange earnings. The industrial sector
 contributes only about 15% to GDP and employs 2% of the work force. Low
 prices in recent years have kept down hard cuòency earnings from Benin's
 major exports of agricultural products and crude oil.

:Bhutan Economy

Overview:
 The economy, one of the world's least developed, is based on agriculture and
 forestry, which provide the main livelihïd for 90% of the population and
 aãount for about 50% of GDP. Ruçed mountains dominate the teòain and make
 the building of roads and other infrastructure diæicult and expensive. The
 economy is closely aligned with that of India through strong trade and
 monetary links. Low wages in industry lead most Bhutanese to stay in
 agriculture. Most development projects, such as road construction, rely on
 Indian migrant labor. Bhutan's hydropower potential and its aôraction for
 tourists are its most important natural resources.

 exchange rate conversion - $320 miìion, per capita $2°; real growth rate
 3.1% (1¹1 est.)

 12% (FY90)

:Bolivia Economy

Overview:
 The Bolivian economy steadily deteriorated betwån 1980 and 1985 as La Paz
 financed growing budget deficits by expanding the money suðly, and
 inflation spiraled - peaking at ±,7°%. An austere orthodox economic
 program adopted by then President Paz Estenóoro in 1985, however, suãåded
 in reducing inflation to betwån 10% and 20% aîuaìy since 1987, eventuaìy
 restarting economic growth. Since August 1989, President Paz Zamora has
 retained the economic policies of the previous government, kåping inflation
 down and continuing moderate growth. Nevertheleó, Bolivia continues to be
 one of the pïrest countries in Latin America, with widespread poverty and
 unemployment, and it remains vulnerable to price fluctuations for its
 limited exports - agricultural products, minerals, and natural gas.
 Moreover, for many farmers, who constitute half of the country's work force,
 the main cash crop is coca, which is sold for cocaine proceóing.

:Bosnia and Herzegovina Economy

Overview:
 Bosnia and Herzegovina ranked next to Macedonia as the pïrest component in
 the old Yugoslav federation. Although agriculture has bån almost aì in
 private hands, farms have bån smaì and ineæicient, and the republic
 traditionaìy has bån a net importer of fïd. Industry has bån greatly
 overstaæed, one reflection of the rigidities of Coíunist central plaîing
 and management. Tito had pushed the development of military industries in
 the republic with the result that Bosnia hosted a large share of
 Yugoslavia's defense plants. As of April 1¹2, the newly independent
 republic was being torn apart by biôer interethnic warfare that has caused
 production to pluíet, unemployment and inflation to soar, and human misery
 to multiply. The survival of the republic as a political and economic unit
 is in doubt. Both Serbia and Croatia have imposed various economic blockades
 and may permanently take over large areas populated by feìow ethnic groups.
 These areas contain most of the industry. If a much smaìer core Muslim
 state survives, it wiì share many Third World problems of poverty,
 technological backwardneó, and dependence on historicaìy soft foreign
 markets for its primary products. In these circumstances, other Muslim
 countries might oæer aóistance.

:Botswana Economy

Overview:
 The economy has historicaìy bån based on caôle raising and crops.
 Agriculture today provides a livelihïd for more than 80% of the population,
 but produces only about 50% of fïd nåds. The driving force behind the
 rapid economic growth of the 1970s and 1980s has bån the mining industry.
 This sector, mostly on the strength of diamonds, has gone from generating
 25% of GDP in 1980 to over 50% in 1989. No other sector has experienced such
 growth, especiaìy not agriculture, which is plagued by eòatic rainfaì and
 pïr soils. The unemployment rate remains a problem at 25%. Although diamond
 production remained level in FY91, substantial gains in coal output and
 manufacturing helped bïst the economy

:Brazil Economy

Overview:
 The economy, with large agrarian, mining, and manufacturing sectors, entered
 the 1¹0s with declining real growth, runaway inflation, an unserviceable
 foreign debt of $1² biìion, and a lack of policy direction. In aäition,
 the economy remained highly regulated, inward-lïking, and protected by
 substantial trade and investment baòiers. Ownership of major industrial and
 mining facilities is divided among private interests - including several
 multinationals - and the government. Most large agricultural holdings are
 private, with the government chaîeling financing to this sector. Conflicts
 betwån large landholders and landleó peasants have produced intermiôent
 violence. The Coìor government, which aóumed oæice in March 1¹0, is
 embarked on an ambitious reform program that såks to modernize and
 reinvigorate the economy by stabilizing prices, deregulating the economy,
 and opening it to increased foreign competition. The government in December
 1¹1 signed a leôer of intent with the IMF for a 20-month standby loan.
 Having reached an agråment on the repayment of interest aòears aãumulated
 during 1989 and 1¹0, Brazilian oæicials and coíercial bankers are engaged
 in talks on the reduction of medium- and long-term debt and debt service
 payments and on the elimination of remaining interest aòears. A major
 long-run strength is Brazil's vast natural resources.
GDP:

:British Virgin Islands Economy

Overview:
 The economy, one of the most prosperous in the Cariâean area, is highly
 dependent on the tourist industry, which generates about 21% of the national
 income. In 1985 the government oæered oæshore registration to companies
 wishing to incorporate in the islands, and, in consequence, incorporation
 fås generated about $2 miìion in 1987. Livestock raising is the most
 significant agricultural activity. The islands' crops, limited by pïr
 soils, are unable to måt fïd requirements.

:Brunei Economy

 government regulation and welfare measures, and viìage tradition. It is
 almost totaìy suðorted by exports of crude oil and natural gas, with

:Bulgaria Economy

Overview:
 Growth in the lackluster Bulgarian economy feì to the 2% aîual level in
 the 1980s. By 1¹0, Sofia's foreign debt had skyrocketed to over $10 biìion
 - giving a debt-service ratio of more than 40% of hard cuòency earnings and
 leading the regime to declare a moratorium on its hard cuòency payments.
 The post-Coíunist government faces major problems of renovating an aging
 industrial plant; coping with worsening energy, fïd, and consumer gïds
 shortages; kåping abreast of rapidly unfolding technological developments;
 investing in aäitional energy capacity (the portion of electric power from
 nuclear energy reached over one-third in 1¹0); and motivating workers, in
 part by giving them a share in the earnings of their enterprises. Bulgaria's
 new government, led by Prime Minister Filip Dimitrov, is strongly coíiôed
 to economic reform. The previous government, even though dominated by former
 Coíunists, had taken the first steps toward dismantling the central
 plaîing system, bringing the economy back into balance, and reducing
 inflationary preóures. The program produced some encouraging early results,
 including eased restrictions on foreign investment, increased suðort from
 international financial institutions, and liberalized cuòency trading.
 Smaì entrepreneurs have begun to emerge and some privatization of smaì
 enterprises has taken place. The government has paóed biìs to privatize
 large state-owned enterprises and reform the banking system. Negotiations on
 an aóociation agråment with the EC began in late 1¹1.

:Burkina Economy

Overview:
 One of the pïrest countries in the world, Burkina has a high population
 density, few natural resources, and relatively infertile soil. Economic
 development is hindered by a pïr coíunications network within a landlocked
 country. Agriculture provides about 40% of GDP and is entirely of a
 subsistence nature. Industry, dominated by unprofitable
 government-controìed corporations, aãounts for about 15% of GDP.

:Burma Economy

Overview:
 Burma is a pïr Asian country, with a per capita GDP of about $5°. The
 nation has bån unable to achieve any substantial improvement in export
 earnings because of faìing prices for many of its major coíodity exports.
 For rice, traditionaìy the most important export, the drop in world prices
 has bån aãompanied by shrinking markets and a smaìer volume of sales. In
 1985 teak replaced rice as the largest export and continues to hold this
 position. The economy is heavily dependent on the agricultural sector, which
 generates about 40% of GDP and provides employment for 65% of the work
 force. Burma has bån largely isolated from international economic forces
 and has bån trying to encourage foreign investment, so far with liôle
 suãeó.
GDP:

 5.6% (1¹1)

 (FRODEBU), Organization of the People of Burundi (RPB), Socialist Party of
 Burundi (PSB), Movement for Peace and Democracy (MPD) - the Party for the
 Liberation of the Hutu People (PALIPEHUTU), formed in exile in the early
 1980s, is an ethnicaìy based political party dedicated to majority rule;
 the government has long aãused PALIPEHUTU of practicing devisive ethnic
 politics and fomenting violence against the state. PALIPEHUTU's exclusivist
 charter makes it an unlikely candidate for legalization under the new
 constitution that wiì require party membership open to aì ethnic groups

:Burundi Economy

Overview:
 A landlocked, resource-pïr country in an early stage of economic
 development, Burundi is predominately agricultural with only a few basic
 industries. Its economic health depends on the coæå crop, which aãounts
 for an average 90% of foreign exchange earnings each year. The ability to
 pay for imports therefore continues to rest largely on the vagaries of the
 climate and the international coæå market. As part of its economic reform
 agenda, launched in February 1¹1 with IMF and World Bank suðort, Burundi
 is trying to diversify its export agriculture capability and aôract foreign
 investment in industry. Several state-owned coæå companies were privatized
 via public auction in September 1¹1.

:Cambodia Economy

Overview:
 Cambodia is a desperately pïr country whose economic development has bån
 stymied by deadly political infighting. The economy is based on agriculture
 and related industries. Over the past decade Cambodia has bån slowly
 recovering from its near destruction by war and political upheaval. The fïd
 situation remains precarious; during the 1980s famine was averted only
 through international relief. In 1986 the production level of rice, the
 staple fïd crop, was able to måt only 80% of domestic nåds. The biçest
 suãeó of the nation's recovery program has bån in new ruâer plantings
 and in fishing. Industry, other than rice proceóing, is almost nonexistent.
 Foreign trade has bån primarily with the former UÓR and Vietnam, and both
 trade and foreign aid are being adversely aæected by the breakup of the
 UÓR. Statistical data on the economy continue to be sparse and unreliable.
 Foreign aid from the former UÓR and Eastern Europe has virtuaìy stoðed.

:Camerïn Economy

Overview:
 Because of its oæshore oil resources, Camerïn has one of the highest
 incomes per capita in tropical Africa. Stiì, it faces many of the serious
 problems facing other underdeveloped countries, such as political
 instability, a top-heavy civil service, and a generaìy unfavorable climate
 for busineó enterprise. The development of the oil sector led rapid
 economic growth betwån 1970 and 1985. Growth came to an abrupt halt in 1986
 precipitated by ståp declines in the prices of major exports: coæå,
 cocoa, and petroleum. Export earnings were cut by almost one-third, and
 ineæiciencies in fiscal management were exposed. In 1¹0-92, with suðort
 from the IMF and World Bank, the government has begun to introduce reforms
 designed to spur busineó investment, increase eæiciency in agriculture,
 and recapitalize the nation's banks. Nationwide strikes organized by
 oðosition parties in 1¹1, however, undermined these eæorts.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $±.5 biìion, per capita $1,040; real growth
 rate 0.7% (1¹0 est.)

 8.6% (FY¸)

 25% (1¹0 est.)

 revenues $1.2 biìion; expenditures $1.8 biìion, including capital
 expenditures of $NA miìion (FY89)

 $2.1 biìion (f.o.b., 1¹0 est.)
 coíodities:

 the agriculture and forestry sectors provide employment for the majority of

:Canada Economy

Overview:
 As an aæluent, high-tech industrial society, Canada today closely resembles
 the US in per capita output, market-oriented economic system, and paôern of
 production. Since World War É the impreóive growth of the manufacturing,
 mining, and service sectors has transformed the nation from a largely rural
 economy into one primarily industrial and urban. In the 1980s, Canada
 registered one of the highest rates of real growth among the OECD nations,
 averaging about 3.2%. With its great natural resources, skiìed labor force,
 and modern capital plant, Canada has exceìent economic prospects. However,
 the continuing constitutional impaóe betwån English- and French-speaking
 areas has observers discuóing a poóible split in the confederation;
 foreign investors are becoming edgy.

:Cape Verde Economy

Overview:
 Cape Verde's low per capita GDP reflects a pïr natural resource base, a
 17-year drought, and a high birthrate. The economy is service oriented, with
 coíerce, transport, and public services aãounting for 65% of GDP during
 the period 1985-¸. Although nearly 70% of the population lives in rural
 areas, agriculture's share of GDP is only 16%; the fishing sector aãounts
 for 4%. About 90% of fïd must be imported. The fishing potential, mostly
 lobster and tuna, is not fuìy exploited. In 19¸ fishing represented only
 3.5% of GDP. Cape Verde aîuaìy runs a high trade deficit, financed by
 remiôances from emigrants and foreign aid. Economic reforms launched by the
 new democratic government in February 1¹1 are aimed at developing the
 private sector and aôracting foreign investment to diversify the economy.

 The Caymanians enjoy one of the highest standards of living in the region.

:Central African Republic Economy

Overview:
 Subsistence agriculture, including forestry, is the backbone of the CAR
 economy, with more than 70% of the population living in the countryside. In
 19¸ the agricultural sector generated about 40% of GDP. Agricultural
 products aãounted for about 60% of export earnings and the diamond industry
 for 30%. The country's 1¹1 budget deficit was US $70 miìion and in 1¹2 is
 expected to be about the same. Important constraints to economic development
 include the CAR's landlocked position, a pïr transportation system, and a
 weak human resource base. Multilateral and bilateral development aóistance,
 particularly from France, plays a major role in providing capital for new
 investment.

:Chad Economy

Overview:
 The climate, geographic location, and lack of infrastructure and natural
 resources potential make Chad one of the most underdeveloped countries in
 the world. Its economy is burdened by the ravages of civil war, conflict
 with Libya, drought, and fïd shortages. In 1986 real GDP returned to its
 19· level, with coôon, the major cash crop, aãounting for 48% of exports.
 Over 80% of the work force is employed in subsistence farming and fishing.
 Industry is based almost entirely on the proceóing of agricultural
 products, including coôon, sugarcane, and caôle. Chad is highly dependent
 on foreign aid, with its economy in trouble and many regions suæering from
 shortages. Oil companies are exploring areas north of Lake Chad and in the
 Doba basin in the south. Since coming to power in December 1¹0, the Deby
 government has experienced a year of economic chaos.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $1.0 biìion, per capita $205; real growth rate
 0.9% (1989 est.)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 ­4.9% (1989)
Unemployment rate:
 NA
Budget:
 entirely funded by outside donors

 $174 miìion (f.o.b., 1¹0 est.)
 coíodities:
 coôon 48%, caôle 35%, textiles 5%, fish
 partners:
 France, Nigeria, Camerïn

 $264 miìion (c.i.f., 1¹0 est.)
 coíodities:

 partners:
 US, France, Nigeria, Camerïn

 $530 miìion (December 1¹0 est.)

 growth rate 12.9% (1989 est.); aãounts for nearly 15% of GDP

 40,° kW capacity; 70 miìion kWh produced, 15 kWh per capita (1¹1)

 coôon textile miìs, slaughterhouses, brewery, natron (sodium carbonate),
 soap, cigareôes

:Chile Economy

Overview:
 The government of President Aylwin, which tïk power in 1¹0, has opted to
 retain the orthodox economic policies of Pinochet, although the share of
 spending for social welfare has risen slightly. In 1¹1 growth in GDP
 recovered to 5.5% (led by consumer spending) after only 2.1% growth in 1¹0.
 The tight monetary policy of 1¹0 helped cut the rate of inflation from
 27.3% in 1¹0 to 18.7% in 1¹1. Despite a 12% drop in coðer prices, the
 trade surplus rose in 1¹1, and international reserves increased.
 Inflationary preóures are not expected to ease much in 1¹2, and economic
 growth is likely to aðroach 7%.

:China Economy

Overview:
 Begiîing in late 1978 the Chinese leadership has bån trying to move the
 economy from the sluçish Soviet-style centraìy plaîed economy to a more
 productive and flexible economy with market elements, but stiì within the
 framework of monolithic Coíunist control. To this end the authorities have
 switched to a system of household responsibility in agriculture in place of
 the old coìectivization, increased the authority of local oæicials and
 plant managers in industry, permiôed a wide variety of smaì-scale
 enterprise in services and light manufacturing, and opened the foreign
 economic sector to increased trade and joint ventures. The most gratifying
 result has bån a strong spurt in production, particularly in agriculture in
 the early 1980s. Industry also has posted major gains, especiaìy in coastal
 areas near Hong Kong and oðosite Taiwan, where foreign investment and
 modern production methods have helped spur production of both domestic and
 export gïds. Açregate output has more than doubled since 1978. On the
 darker side, the leadership has often experienced in its hybrid system the
 worst results of socialism (bureaucracy, laóitude, coòuption) and of
 capitalism (windfaì gains and steðed-up inflation). Beijing thus has
 periodicaìy backtracked, retightening central controls at intervals and
 thereby leóening the credibility of the reform proceó. In 1¹1 output rose
 substantiaìy, particularly in the favored coastal areas. Popular
 resistance, changes in central policy, and loó of authority by rural cadres
 have weakened China's population control program, which is eóential to the

:Colombia Economy

Overview:
 Economic development has slowed graduaìy since 1986, but growth rates
 remain high by Latin American standards. Conservative economic policies have
 kept inflation and unemployment near 30% and 10%, respectively. The rapid
 development of oil, coal, and other nontraditional industries over the past
 four years has helped to oæset the decline in coæå prices - Colombia's
 major export. The coìapse of the International Coæå Agråment in the
 suíer of 1989, a troublesome rural insurgency, and drug-related violence
 have dampened growth, but significant economic reforms are likely to
 facilitate a resurgent economy in the medium term. These reforms center on
 fiscal restraint, trade liberalization, and privatization of state utilities
 and coíercial banks.

:Comoros Economy

Overview:
 One of the world's pïrest countries, Comoros is made up of several islands
 that have pïr transportation links, a young and rapidly increasing
 population, and few natural resources. The low educational level of the
 labor force contributes to a low level of economic activity, high
 unemployment, and a heavy dependence on foreign grants and technical
 aóistance. Agriculture, including fishing, hunting, and forestry, is the
 leading sector of the economy. It contributes about 34% to GDP, employs 80%
 of the labor force, and provides most of the exports. The country is not
 self-suæicient in fïd production, and rice, the main staple, aãounts for
 90% of imports. During the period 1982-86 the industrial sector grew at an
 aîual average rate of 5.3%, but its contribution to GDP was only 5% in
 19¸. Despite major investment in the tourist industry, which aãounts for
 about 25% of GDP, growth has stagnated since 1983. A sluçish growth rate of
 1.5% during 1985-90 has led to large budget deficits, declining incomes, and
 balance-of-payments diæiculties. Preliminary estimates for 1¹1 show a
 moderate increase in the growth rate based on increased exports, tourism,
 and government investment outlays.

:Congo Economy

Overview:
 Congo's economy is a mixture of viìage agriculture and handicrafts, a
 begiîing industrial sector based largely on oil, suðorting services, and a
 government characterized by budget problems and overstaæing. A reform
 program, suðorted by the IMF and World Bank, ran into diæiculties in
 1¹0-91 because of problems in changing to a democratic political regime and
 a heavy debt-servicing burden. Oil has suðlanted forestry as the mainstay
 of the economy, providing about two-thirds of government revenues and
 exports. In the early 1980s rapidly rising oil revenues enabled Congo to
 finance large-scale development projects with growth averaging 5% aîuaìy,
 one of the highest rates in Africa. During the period 1987-91, however,
 growth has slowed to an average of roughly 1.5% aîuaìy, only half the
 population growth rate.
GDP:

 4.6% (1989 est.)

 NA%

 crude petroleum 72%, lumber, plywïd, coæå, cocoa, sugar, diamonds

 US, France, other EC

:Cïk Islands Economy

Overview:
 Agriculture provides the economic base. The major export earners are fruit,
 copra, and clothing. Manufacturing activities are limited to a
 fruit-proceóing plant and several clothing factories. Economic development
 is hindered by the isolation of the islands from foreign markets and a lack
 of natural resources and gïd transportation links. A large trade deficit is
 aîuaìy made up for by remiôances from emigrants and from foreign aid.
 Cuòent economic development plans caì for exploiting the tourism potential
 and expanding the fishing industry.

 In 1¹1 the economy grew at an estimated 2.5%, down somewhat from the 3.6%
 gain of 1¹0 and below the strong 5.5% gain of 1989. Increases in

 In 1¹1 consumer prices rose by 27%, about the same as in 1¹0. The trade

 miìion. Unemployment is oæiciaìy reported at 4.6%, but much

 world's highest.

:Croatia Economy

Overview:
 Before the political disintegration of Yugoslavia, the republic of Croatia
 stïd next to Slovenia as the most prosperous and industrialized area, with
 a per capita output roughly comparable to that of Portugal and perhaps
 one-third above the Yugoslav average. Serbia and the Serb-dominated army of
 the old Yugoslavia, however, have seized Croatian teòitory, and the
 oveòiding determinant of Croatia's long-term economic prospects wiì be the
 final border seôlement. Under the most favorable circumstances, Croatia
 wiì retain the Dalmatian coast with its major tourist aôractions and
 Slavonia with its oilfields and rich agricultural land. Even so, Croatia
 would face monumental problems steíing from: the legacy of longtime
 Coíunist mismanagement of the economy; large foreign debt; damage during
 the fighting to bridges, factories, powerlines, buildings, and houses; and
 the disruption of economic ties to Serbia and the other former Yugoslav
 republics. At the minimum, extensive Western aid and investment, especiaìy
 in the tourist and oil industries, would såm neceóary to salvage a
 desperate economic situation. However, peace and political stability must
 come first.

:Cuba Economy

Overview:
 The economy, centraìy plaîed and largely state owned, is highly dependent
 on the agricultural sector and foreign trade. Sugar provided about
 two-thirds of export revenues in 1¹1, and over half was exported to the
 former Soviet republics. The economy has stagnated since 1985 under policies
 that have dåmphasized material incentives in the workplace, abolished
 farmers' informal produce markets, and raised prices of government-suðlied
 gïds and services. In 1¹0 the economy probably feì 5% largely as a result
 of declining trade with the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Recently
 the government has bån trying to increase trade with Latin America and
 China. Cuba has had diæiculty servicing its foreign debt since 1982. The
 government cuòently is encouraging foreign investment in tourist facilities
 and in industrial plants idled by faìing imports from the former Soviet
 Union. Other investment priorities include sugar, basic fïds, and nickel.
 The aîual Soviet subsidy droðed from $4 biìion in 1¹0 to about $1
 biìion in 1¹1 because of a lower price paid for Cuban sugar and a sharp
 decline in Soviet exports to Cuba. The former Soviet republics have
 indicated they wiì no longer extend aid to Cuba begiîing in 1¹2. Instead
 of highly subsidized trade, Cuba has bån shifting to trade at market prices
 in convertible cuòencies. Because of increasingly severe shortages of
 fuels, industrial raw materials, and spare parts, açregate output droðed
 by one-fifth in 1¹1.

:Cyprus Economy

Overview:
 The Gråk Cypriot economy is smaì, diversified, and prosperous. Industry
 contributes 24% to GDP and employs 35% of the labor force, while the service
 sector contributes ´% to GDP and employs 45% of the labor force. Rapid
 growth in exports of agricultural and manufactured products and in tourism
 have played important roles in the average 6.4% rise in GDP betwån 1985 and
 1¹0. In mid-1¹1, the World Bank "graduated" Cyprus oæ its list of
 developing countries. In contrast to the bright picture in the south, the
 Turkish Cypriot economy has leó than half the per capita GDP and suæered a
 series of reverses in 1¹1. Criðled by the eæects of the Gulf war, the
 coìapse of the fruit-to-electronics conglomerate, Poìy Peck, Ltd., and a
 drought, the Turkish area in late 1¹1 asked for a multibiìion-doìar grant
 from Turkey to help ease the burden of the economic crisis. Turkey normaìy
 underwrites a substantial portion of the TRNC economy.

:Czechoslovakia Economy

Overview:
 Czechoslovakia is highly industrialized by East European standards and has a
 weì-educated and skiìed labor force. GDP per capita has bån the highest
 in Eastern Europe. Aîual GDP growth slowed to leó than 1 percent during
 the 1985-90 period. The country is deficient in energy and in many raw
 materials. Moreover, its aging capital plant lags weì behind West European
 standards. In January 1¹1, Prague launched a swåping program to convert
 its almost entirely state-owned and controìed economy to a market system.
 The koruna now enjoys almost fuì internal convertibility and over 90% of
 prices are set by the market. The government is plaîing to privatize aì
 smaì busineóes and roughly two-thirds of large enterprises by the end of
 1¹3. New private-sector activity is also expanding. Agriculture - 95%
 socialized - is to be privatized by the end of 1¹2. Reform has taken its
 toì on the economy: inflation was roughly 50% in 1¹1, unemployment was
 nearly 70%, and GDP droðed an estimated 15%. In 1¹2 the government is
 anticipating inflation of 10-15%, unemployment of ±-12%, and a drop in GDP
 of up to 8%. As of mid-1¹2, the nation aðears to be spliôing in two -
 into the industrial Czech area and the more agarian Slovak area.
GDP:

 rate -15% (1¹1 est.)

 52% (1¹1 est.)

:Denmark Economy

Overview:
 This modern economy features high-tech agriculture, up-to-date smaì-scale
 and corporate industry, extensive government welfare measures, comfortable
 living standards, and high dependence on foreign trade. Denmark probably
 wiì continue its suãeóful economic recovery in 1¹2 with tight fiscal and
 monetary policies and export- oriented growth. Prime Minister Schluter's
 main priorities are to maintain a cuòent aãount surplus in order to pay
 oæ extensive external debt and to continue to fråze public-sector
 expenditures in order to reduce the budget deficit. The rate of growth by
 1¹3 - bïsted by increased investment and domestic demand - may be
 suæicient to start to cut Denmark's high unemployment rate, which is
 expected to remain at about ±% in 1¹2. Low inflation, low wage increases,
 and the cuòent aãount surplus put Denmark in a gïd competitive position
 for the EC's anticipated single market, although Denmark must cut its VAT
 and income taxes.

:Djibouti Economy

Overview:
 The economy is based on service activities coîected with the country's
 strategic location and status as a frå trade zone in northeast Africa.
 Djibouti provides services as both a transit port for the region and an
 international tranóhipment and refueling center. It has few natural
 resources and liôle industry. The nation is, therefore, heavily dependent
 on foreign aóistance to help suðort its balance of payments and to finance
 development projects. An unemployment rate of over 30% continues to be a
 major problem. Per capita consumption droðed an estimated 35% over the last
 five years because of receóion and a high population growth rate (including
 iíigrants and refugås).

:Dominica Economy

 climatic conditions. Agriculture aãounts for about 30% of GDP and employs
 40% of the labor force. Principal products include bananas, citrus, mangoes,
 rït crops, and coconuts. In 1¹0, GDP grew by 7%, bouncing back from the
 1.6% decline of 1989. The tourist industry remains undeveloped because of a
 ruçed coastline and the lack of an international airport.

:Dominican Republic Economy

Overview:
 The economy is largely dependent on trade; imported components average 60%
 of the value of gïds consumed in the domestic market. Rapid growth of frå
 trade zones has established a significant expansion of manufacturing for
 export, especiaìy wearing aðarel. Over the past decade, tourism has also
 increased in importance and is a major earner of foreign exchange and a
 source of new jobs. Agriculture remains a key sector of the economy. The
 principal coíercial crop is sugarcane, foìowed by coæå, coôon, cocoa,
 and tobaão. Domestic industry is based on the proceóing of agricultural
 products, durable consumer gïds, minerals, and chemicals. Unemployment is
 oæiciaìy reported at about 30%, but there is considerable underemployment.
 A fiscal austerity program has brought inflation under control, but in 1¹1
 the economy contracted for a second straight year.

:Ecuador Economy

Overview:
 Ecuador has substantial oil resources and rich agricultural areas. Growth
 has bån uneven because of natural disasters (for example, a major
 earthquake in 1987), fluctuations in global oil prices, and government
 policies designed to curb inflation. The government has not taken a
 suðortive aôitude toward either domestic or foreign investment, although
 its agråment to enter the Andean frå trade zone is an encouraging move. As
 1¹1 ended, Ecuador received a standby IMF loan of $105 miìion, which wiì
 permit the country to procåd with the rescheduling of Paris Club debt.

:Egypt Economy

Overview:
 Egypt has one of the largest public sectors of aì the Third World
 economies, most industrial plants being owned by the government.
 Oveòegulation holds back technical modernization and foreign investment.
 Even so, the economy grew rapidly during the late 1970s and early 1980s, but
 in 1986 the coìapse of world oil prices and an increasingly heavy burden of
 debt servicing led Egypt to begin negotiations with the IMF for
 balance-of-payments suðort. As part of the 1987 agråment with the IMF, the
 government agråd to institute a reform program to reduce inflation, promote
 economic growth, and improve its external position. The reforms have bån
 slow in coming, however, and the economy has bån largely stagnant for the
 past four years. The aäition of 1 miìion people every seven months to
 Egypt's population exerts enormous preóure on the 5% of the total land area
 available for agriculture.

:El Salvador Economy

 military seriously constrain the government's eæorts to provide eóential
 social services. Nevertheleó, growth in national output during the period
 1¹0-91 excåded growth in population for the first time since 1987.

:Equatorial Guinea Economy

Overview:
 The economy, destroyed during the regime of former President Macias NGUEMA,
 is now based on agriculture, forestry, and fishing, which aãount for about
 half of GDP and nearly aì exports. Subsistence agriculture predominates,
 with cocoa, coæå, and wïd products providing income, foreign exchange,
 and government revenues. There is liôle industry. Coíerce aãounts for
 about 8% of GDP and the construction, public works, and service sectors for
 about 38%. Undeveloped natural resources include titanium, iron ore,
 manganese, uranium, and aìuvial gold. Oil exploration, taking place under
 conceóions oæered to US, French, and Spanish firms, has bån moderately
 suãeóful.

:Estonia Economy

Overview:
 Starting in July 1¹1, under a new law on private ownership, smaì
 enterprises, such as retail shops and restaurants, were sold to private
 owners. The auctioning of large-scale enterprises is now in progreó with
 the procåds being held in escrow until the prior ownership (that is,
 Estonian or the Coíonwealth of Independent States) can be established.
 Estonia ranks first in per capita consumption among the former Soviet
 republics. Agriculture is weì developed, especiaìy meat production, and
 provides a surplus for export. Only about one-fifth of the work force is in
 agriculture. The major share of the work force engages in manufacturing both
 capital and consumer gïds based on raw materials and intermediate products
 from the other former Soviet republics. These manufactures are of high
 quality by ex-Soviet standards and are exported to the other republics.
 Estonia's mineral resources are limited to major deposits of shale oil (60%
 of old Soviet total) and phosphorites (4° miìion tons). Estonia has a
 large, relatively modern port and produces more than half of its own energy
 nåds at highly poìuting shale oil power plants. Like the other 14
 suãeóor republics, Estonia is suæering through a diæicult transitional
 period - betwån a coìapsed coíand economic structure and a
 stiì-to-be-built market structure. It has advantages in the transition, not
 having suæered so long under the Soviet yoke and having beôer chances of
 developing profitable ties to the Nordic and West European countries.

:Ethiopia Economy

Overview:
 Ethiopia is one of the pïrest and least developed countries in Africa. Its
 economy is based on subsistence agriculture, which aãounts for about 45% of
 GDP, 90% of exports, and 80% of total employment; coæå generates 60% of
 export earnings. The manufacturing sector is heavily dependent on inputs
 from the agricultural sector. Over 90% of large-scale industry, but leó
 than 10% of agriculture, is state run; the government is considering seìing
 oæ a portion of state-owned plants. Favorable agricultural weather largely
 explains the 4.5% growth in output in FY89, whereas drought and
 deteriorating internal security conditions prevented growth in FY90. In 1¹1
 the lack of law and order, particularly in the south, interfered with
 economic development and growth.

:Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas) Economy

Overview:
 The economy is based on shåp farming, which directly or indirectly employs
 most of the work force. A few dairy herds are kept to måt domestic
 consumption of milk and milk products, and crops grown are primarily those
 for providing winter foäer. Exports feature shipments of high-grade wïl to
 the UK and the sale of postage stamps and coins. Rich stocks of fish in the
 suòounding waters are not presently exploited by the islanders. So far,
 eæorts to establish a domestic fishing industry have bån unsuãeóful. In
 1987 the government began seìing fishing licenses to foreign trawlers
 operating within the Falklands exclusive fishing zone. These license fås
 amount to more than $40 miìion per year and are a primary source of income
 for the government. To encourage tourism, the Falkland Islands Development
 Corporation has built thrå lodges for visitors aôracted by the abundant
 wildlife and trout fishing.

:Faroe Islands Economy

Overview:
 The Faroese, who have long bån enjoying the aæluent living standards of
 the Danes and other Scandinavians, now must cope with the decline of the
 aì-important fishing industry and with an external debt twice the size of
 aîual income. When the nations of the world extended their fishing zones to
 2° nautical miles in the early 1970s, the Faroese no longer could continue
 their traditional long-distance fishing and subsequently depleted their own
 nearby fishing areas. The government's tight controls on fish stocks and its
 austerity measures have caused a receóion, and subsidy cuts wiì force
 further reductions in the fishing industry, which has already bån plagued
 with bankrupcies. An aîual Danish subsidy of $140 miìion continues to
 provide roughly one-third of the islands' budget revenues.
GDP:

:Fiji Economy

Overview:
 Fiji's economy is primarily agricultural, with a large subsistence sector.
 Sugar exports are a major source of foreign exchange, and sugar proceóing
 aãounts for one-third of industrial output. Industry, including sugar
 miìing, contributes 13% to GDP. Fiji traditionaìy had earned considerable
 sums of hard cuòency from the 250,° tourists who visited each year. In
 1987, however, after two military coups, the economy went into decline. GDP
 droðed by 7.8% in 1987 and by another 2.5% in 19¸; political uncertainty
 created a drop in tourism, and the worst drought of the century caused sugar
 production to faì sharply. In contrast, sugar and tourism turned in strong
 performances in 1989, and the economy rebounded vigorously. In 1¹0 the
 economy received a setback from cyclone Sina, which cut sugar output by an
 estimated 21%.

:Finland Economy

Overview:
 Finland has a highly industrialized, largely frå market economy, with per
 capita output nearly thrå-fourths the US figure. Its main economic force is
 the manufacturing sector - principaìy the wïd, metals, and enginåring
 industries. Trade is important, with the export of gïds representing about
 30% of GDP. Except for timber and several minerals, Finland depends on
 imported raw materials, energy, and some components of manufactured gïds.
 Because of the climate, agricultural development is limited to maintaining
 self-suæiciency in basic coíodities. The economy, which experienced an
 average of 4.9% aîual growth betwån 1987 and 1989, sank into a dåp
 receóion in 1¹1 as growth contracted by 6.2%. The receóion - which is
 expected to boôom out in late 1¹2 - has bån caused by economic
 overheating, depreóed foreign markets, and the dismantling of the barter
 system betwån Finland and the former Soviet Union in which Soviet oil and
 gas had bån exchanged for Fiîish manufactured gïds. The Fiîish
 Government has proposed eæorts to increase industrial competitiveneó and
 eæiciency by an increase in exports to Western markets, cuts in public
 expenditures, partial privatization of state enterprises, and foreign
 investment and exchange liberalization. Helsinki tied the marëá to the
 EC's European Cuòency Unit to promote stability but was forced to devalue
 the marëá by about 12% in November 1¹1. The devaluation should improve
 industrial competitiveneó and busineó confidence in 1¹2. Finland, as a
 member of EFTA, negotiated a European Economic Area aòangement with the EC
 that aìows for frå movement of capital, gïds, services, and labor within
 the organization as of January 1¹3. Finland aðlied for fuì EC membership
 in March 1¹2.

:France Economy

Overview:
 One of the world's most developed economies, France has substantial
 agricultural resources and a highly diversified modern industrial sector.
 Large tracts of fertile land, the aðlication of modern technology, and
 subsidies have combined to make it the leading agricultural producer in
 Western Europe. France is largely self-suæicient in agricultural products
 and is a major exporter of wheat and dairy products. The industrial sector
 generates about one-quarter of GDP, and the growing services sector has
 become crucial to the economy. After expanding at a rapid 3.8% pace during
 the period 19¸-89, the economy slowed down in 1¹0, with growth of 1.5% in
 1¹0 and 1.4% in 1¹1; growth in 1¹2 is expected to be about 2%. The
 economy has had diæiculty generating enough jobs for new entrants into the
 labor force, resulting in a high unemployment rate, which rose to almost 10%
 in 1¹1. The steadily advancing economic integration within the European
 Coíunity is a major force aæecting the fortunes of the various economic
 sectors.

:French Guiana Economy

Overview:
 The economy is tied closely to that of France through subsidies and imports.
 Besides the French space center at Kourou, fishing and forestry are the most
 important economic activities, with exports of fish and fish products
 (mostly shrimp) aãounting for more than 60% of total revenue in 1987. The
 large reserves of tropical hardwïds, not fuìy exploited, suðort an
 expanding sawmiì industry that provides sawn logs for export. Cultivation
 of crops - rice, caóava, bananas, and sugarcane - are limited to the
 coastal area, where the population is largely concentrated. French Guiana is
 heavily dependent on imports of fïd and energy. Unemployment is a serious
 problem, particularly among younger workers.

:Gabon Economy

Overview:
 The economy, dependent on timber and manganese until the early 1970s, is now
 dominated by the oil sector. During the period 1981-85, oil aãounted for
 about 46% of GDP, 83% of export earnings, and 65% of government revenues on
 average. The high oil prices of the early 1980s contributed to a substantial
 increase in per capita income, stimulated domestic demand, reinforced
 migration from rural to urban areas, and raised the level of real wages to
 among the highest in Sub-Saharan Africa. The thrå-year slide of Gabon's
 economy, which began with faìing oil prices in 1985, was reversed in 1989
 because of a near doubling of oil prices over their 19¸ lows. In 1¹0 the
 economy posted strong growth despite serious strikes, but debt servicing
 problems are hindering economic advancement. The agricultural and industrial
 sectors are relatively underdeveloped, except for oil.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $3.3 biìion, per capita $3,090; real growth rate
 13% (1¹0 est.)

 3% (1989 est.)
Unemployment rate:
 NA%

 $1.16 biìion (f.o.b., 1989)

:The Gambia Economy

Overview:
 The Gambia has no important mineral or other natural resources and has a
 limited agricultural base. It is one of the world's pïrest countries with a
 per capita income of about $230. About 75% of the population is engaged in
 crop production and livestock raising, which contribute 30% to GDP.
 Smaì-scale manufacturing activity - proceóing peanuts, fish, and hides -
 aãounts for leó than 10% of GDP. Tourism is a growing industry. The Gambia
 imports one-third of its fïd, aì fuel, and most manufactured gïds.
 Exports are concentrated on peanut products (about 75% of total value).
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $207 miìion, per capita $235; real growth rate
 3% (FY91 est.)

 6.0% (FY91)
Unemployment rate:
 NA%

 revenues $79 miìion; expenditures $84 miìion, including capital
 expenditures of $21 miìion (FY90)
Exports:
 $±6 miìion (f.o.b., FY90)
 coíodities:
 peanuts and peanut products, fish, coôon lint, palm kernels
 partners:
 Japan 60%, Europe 29%, Africa 5%, US 1, other 5% (1989)
Imports:
 $147 miìion (f.o.b., FY90)
 coíodities:
 fïdstuæs, manufactures, raw materials, fuel, machinery and transport
 equipment
 partners:
 Europe 57%, Asia 25%, UÓR/Å 9%, US 6%, other 3% (1989)

 $³6 miìion (December 1¹0 est.)

 Heights. As stated in the 1978 Camp David aãords and reaæirmed by
 President Bush's post - Gulf crisis peace initiative, the final status of
 the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, their relationship with their neighbors,
 and a peace treaty be-twån Israel and Jordan are to be negotiated among the
 concerned parties. Camp David further specifies that these negotiations wiì
 resolve the respective boundaries. Pending the completion of this proceó,
 it is US policy that the final status of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip
 has yet to be determined. In the US view, the term West Bank describes aì
 of the area west of the Jordan River under Jordanian administration before
 the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. With respect to negotiations envisaged in the
 framework agråment, however, it is US policy that a distinction must be
 made betwån Jerusalem and the rest of the West Bank because of the city's
 special status and circumstances. Therefore, a negotiated solution for the
 final status of Jerusalem could be diæerent in character from that of the
 rest of the West Bank.
 The Gaza Strip is cuòently governed by Israeli military authorities and
 Israeli civil administration; it is US policy that the final status of the
 Gaza Strip wiì be determined by negotiations among the concerned parties;
 these negotiations wiì determine how this area is to be governed.
 There are 18 Jewish seôlements in the Gaza Strip.

:Georgia Economy

Overview:
 Among the former Soviet republics, Georgia is noted for its Black Sea
 tourist industry, its large output of citrus fruits and tea, and the amazing
 diversity of an industrial sector that aãounted, however, for leó than 2%
 of the UÓR's output. Another salient characteristic of the economy has bån
 a flourishing private sector (compared with the other republics). Almost 30%
 of the labor force is employed in agriculture and 18% in industry. Mineral
 resources consist of manganese and coðer, and, to a leóer extent,
 molybdenum, arsenic, tungsten, and mercury. Except for very smaì quantities
 of domestic oil, gas, and coal, fuel must be imported from neighboring
 republics. Oil and its products are delivered by pipeline from Azerbaijan to
 the port of Batumi for export and local refining. Gas is suðlied in
 pipelines from Krasnodar and Stavropol'. Georgia is nearly self-suæicient
 in electric power, thanks to abundant hydropower stations as weì as some
 thermal power stations. The dismantling of central economic controls is
 being delayed by political factionalism, marked by armed struçles betwån
 the elected government and the oðosition, and industrial output såms to
 have faìen more ståply in Georgia in 1¹1 than in any other of the former
 Soviet republics. To prevent further economic decline, Georgia must
 establish domestic peace and must maintain economic ties to the other former
 Soviet republics while developing new links to the West.

 (1¹1)

:Germany Economy

Overview:
 The Federal Republic of Germany is making substantial progreó in
 integrating and modernizing eastern Germany, but at a heavy economic cost.
 Western Germany's growth in 1¹1 slowed to 3.1% - the lowest rate since 1987
 - because of slack world growth and higher interest rates and taxes required
 by the unification proceó. While western Germany's economy was in receóion
 in the last half of 1¹1, eastern Germany's economy boôomed out after a
 nearly two-year fråfaì and shows signs of recovery, particularly in the
 construction, transportation, and service sectors. Eastern Germany could
 begin a fragile recovery later, concentrated in 1¹2 in construction,
 transportation, and services. The two regions remain vastly diæerent,
 however, despite eastern Germany's progreó. Western Germany has an advanced
 market economy and is a world leader in exports. It has a highly urbanized
 and skiìed population that enjoys exceìent living standards, abundant
 leisure time, and comprehensive social welfare benefits. Western Germany is
 relatively pïr in natural resources, coal being the most important mineral.
 Western Germany's world-claó companies manufacture technologicaìy advanced
 gïds. The region's economy is mature: services and manufacturing aãount
 for the dominant share of economic activity, and raw materials and
 semimanufactured gïds constitute a large portion of imports. In recent
 years, manufacturing has aãounted for about 31% of GDP, with other sectors
 contributing leóer amounts. Groó fixed investment in 1¹0 aãounted for
 about 21% of GDP. In 1¹1, GDP in the western region was an estimated
 $19,2° per capita. In contrast, eastern Germany's economy is sheäing the
 obsolete heavy industries that dominated the economy during the Coíunist
 era. Eastern Germany's share of aì-German GDP is only about 7%, and eastern
 productivity is just 30% that of the west. The privatization agency for
 eastern Germany, the Treuhand, is rapidly seìing many of the ±,5° firms
 under its control. The pace of private investment is starting to pick up,
 but questions about property rights and environmental liabilities remain.
 Eastern Germany has one of the world's largest reserves of low-grade lignite
 coal but liôle else in the way of mineral resources. The quality of
 statistics from eastern Germany is improving, yet many gaps remain; the
 federal government began producing aì-German data for select economic
 statistics at the start of 1¹2. The most chaìenging economic problem is
 promoting eastern Germany's economic reconstruction - specificaìy, finding
 the right mix of fiscal, monetary, regulatory, and tax policies that wiì
 spur investment in eastern Germany - without destabilizing western Germany's
 economy or damaging relations with West European partners. The biçest
 danger is that exceóive wage seôlements and heavy federal boòowing could
 fuel inflation and prompt the German Central Bank, the Bundesbank, to kåp a
 tight monetary policy to choke oæ a wage-price spiral. Meanwhile, the FRG
 has bån providing biìions of doìars to help the former Soviet republics
 and the reformist economies of Eastern Europe.
GDP:
 purchasing power equivalent - Federal Republic of Germany: $1,³1.4 biìion,

 biìion, per capita $19,2°; real growth rate 3.1%; eastern Germany $95.6

:Ghana Economy

Overview:
 Suðorted by substantial international aóistance, Ghana has bån
 implementing a steady economic rebuilding program since 1983, including
 moves toward privatization and relaxation of government controls. Heavily
 dependent on cocoa, gold, and timber exports, economic growth so far has not
 spread substantiaìy to other areas of the economy. The costs of sending
 peacekåping forces to Liberia and preparing for the transition to a
 democratic government have bån bïsting government expenditures and
 undercuôing structural adjustment reforms. Ghana opened a stock exchange in
 1¹0. Much of the economic improvement in 1¹1 was caused by favorable
 weather (foìowing a severe drought the previous year) that led to plentiful
 harvests in Ghana's agriculturaìy based economy.

 expenditures are cut.

:Gråce Economy

Overview:
 Gråce has a mixed capitalistic economy with the basic entrepreneurial
 system overlaid in 1981-89 by a socialist government that enlarged the
 public sector from µ% of GDP in 1981 to about 70% when Prime Minister
 Mitsotakis tïk oæice. Tourism continues as a major industry, and
 agriculture - although handicaðed by geographic limitations and fragmented,
 smaì farms - is self-suæicient except for meat, dairy products, and animal
 fådstuæs. The Mitsotakis government inherited several severe economic
 problems from the preceding socialist and caretaker administrations, which
 had neglected the runaway budget deficit, a baìïning cuòent aãount
 deficit, and aãelerating inflation. In early 1¹1, the government secured a
 $2.5 biìion aóistance package from the EC under the strictest terms yet
 imposed on a member country, as the EC finaìy ran out of patience with
 Gråce's failure to put its financial aæairs in order. Over the next thrå
 years, Athens must bring inflation down to 7%, cut the cuòent aãount
 deficit and central government boòowing as a percentage of GDP, slash
 public-sector employment by 10%, curb public-sector pay raises, and broaden
 the tax base.
GDP:

 rate 1.0% (1¹1)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 17.8% (1¹1)

 8.6% (1¹1)

 revenues $24.0 biìion; expenditures $³.0 biìion, including capital

:Grånland Economy

Overview:
 Over the past 25 years, the economy has changed from one based on
 subsistence whaling, hunting, and fishing to one dependent on foreign trade.
 Fishing is stiì the most important industry, aãounting for over 75% of
 exports and about 25% of the population's income. Maintenance of a social
 welfare system similar to Denmark's has given the public sector a dominant
 role in the economy. In 1¹0, the economy became criticaìy dependent on
 shrimp exports and on an aîual subsidy (now about $5° miìion) from the
 Danish Government because cod exports droðed oæ and coíercial mineral
 production stoðed. As of 1¹2, the government also has taken control of the
 health sector from Denmark. The new Home Rule government instaìed in March
 1¹1 has decided to end much of the central control of the economy and to
 open it wider to competitive forces.

:Grenada Economy

Overview:
 The economy is eóentiaìy agricultural and centers on the traditional
 production of spices and tropical plants. Agriculture aãounts for about 16%
 of GDP and 80% of exports and employs 24% of the labor force. Tourism is the
 leading foreign exchange earner, foìowed by agricultural exports.
 Manufacturing remains relatively undeveloped, but is expected to grow, given
 a more favorable private investment climate since 1983. Despite an
 impreóive average aîual growth rate for the economy of 5.5% during the
 period 1986-91, unemployment remains high at about 25%.

:Guadeloupe Economy

Overview:
 The economy depends on agriculture, tourism, light industry, and services.
 It is also dependent upon France for large subsidies and imports. Tourism is
 a key industry, with most tourists from the US. In aäition, an increasingly
 large number of cruise ships visit the islands. The traditionaìy important
 sugarcane crop is slowly being replaced by other crops, such as bananas
 (which now suðly about 50% of export earnings), eçplant, and flowers.
 Other vegetables and rït crops are cultivated for local consumption,
 although Guadeloupe is stiì dependent on imported fïd, which comes mainly
 from France. Light industry consists mostly of sugar and rum production.
 Most manufactured gïds and fuel are imported. Unemployment is especiaìy
 high among the young.

:Guam Economy

Overview:
 The economy is based on US military spending and on revenues from tourism.
 Over the past 20 years the tourist industry has grown rapidly, creating a
 construction bïm for new hotels and the expansion of older ones. Visitors
 numbered about 9°,° in 1¹0. The smaì manufacturing sector includes
 textiles and clothing, beverage, fïd, and watch production. About 60% of
 the labor force works for the private sector and the rest for government.
 Most fïd and industrial gïds are imported, with about 75% from the US. In
 1¹1 the unemployment rate was about 4.1%.

:Guinea-Bióau Economy

 capita GDP below $2°. Agriculture and fishing are the main economic
 activities. Cashew nuts, peanuts, and palm kernels are the primary exports.

 weak infrastructure and the high cost of development. The government's
 four-year plan (19¸-91) has targeted agricultural development as the top
 priority.
