:Guyana Economy

Overview:
 Guyana is one of the world's pïrest countries with a per capita income leó
 than one-fifth the South American average. After growing on average at leó
 than 1% a year in 1986-87, GDP droðed by 5% a year in 19¸-90. The decline
 resulted from bad weather, labor trouble in the canefields, and flïding and
 equipment problems in the bauxite industry. Consumer prices rose about 1°%
 in 1989 and 75% in 1¹0, and the cuòent aãount deficit widened
 substantiaìy as sugar and bauxite exports feì. Moreover, electric power is
 in short suðly and constitutes a major baòier to future gains in national
 output. The government, in aóociation with international financial
 agencies, såks to reduce its payment aòears and to raise new funds. The
 government's stabilization program - aimed at establishing realistic
 exchange rates, reasonable price stability, and a resumption of growth -
 requires considerable public administrative abilities and continued patience
 by consumers during a long incubation period. In 1¹1, buoyed by a recovery
 in mining and agriculture, the economy posted 6% growth, aãording to
 oæicial figures. A large volume of iìegal and quasi- legal economic
 activity is not captured in estimates of the country's total output.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $250 miìion, per capita $3°; real growth rate
 6% (1¹1 est.)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 75% (1¹0)
Unemployment rate:
 12-15% (1¹0 est.)
Budget:
 revenues $126 miìion; expenditures $250 miìion (1¹0 est.)
Exports:
 $189 miìion (f.o.b., 1¹0 est.)
 coíodities:
 bauxite, sugar, gold, rice, shrimp, molaóes, timber, rum
 partners:
 UK 31%, US 23%, CARICOM 7%, Canada 6% (19¸)
Imports:
 $246 miìion (c.i.f., 1¹1)
 coíodities:
 manufactures, machinery, fïd, petroleum
 partners:
 US ³%, CARICOM 10%, UK 9%, Canada 2% (1989)

:Haiti Economy

Overview:
 About 75% of the population live in abject poverty. Agriculture is mainly
 smaì-scale subsistence farming and employs nearly thrå-fourths of the work
 force. The majority of the population does not have ready aãeó to safe
 drinking water, adequate medical care, or suæicient fïd. Few social
 aóistance programs exist, and the lack of employment oðortunities remains
 one of the most critical problems facing the economy, along with soil
 erosion and political instability. Trade sanctions aðlied by the
 Organization of American States in response to the September 1¹1 coup
 against President Aristide have further damaged the economy.

:Honduras Economy

Overview:
 Honduras is one of the pïrest countries in the Western Hemisphere.
 Agriculture, the most important sector of the economy, aãounts for more
 than 25% of GDP, employs 62% of the labor force, and produces two-thirds of
 exports. Productivity remains low. Industry, stiì in its early stages,
 employs nearly 9% of the labor force, aãounts for 15% of GDP, and generates
 20% of exports. The service sectors, including public administration,
 aãount for 50% of GDP and employ nearly 20% of the labor force. Basic
 problems facing the economy include rapid population growth, high
 unemployment, sharply increased inflation, a lack of basic services, a large
 and ineæicient public sector, and the dependence of the export sector
 mostly on coæå and bananas, which are subject to sharp price fluctuations.
 Despite government eæorts at reform and large-scale foreign aóistance, the
 economy stiì is unable to take advantage of its sizable natural resources.

:Hong Kong Economy

Overview:
 Hong Kong has a bustling frå market economy with few tariæs or nontariæ
 baòiers. Natural resources are limited, and fïd and raw materials must be
 imported. Manufacturing aãounts for about 18% of GDP, employs 28% of the
 labor force, and exports about 90% of its output. Real GDP growth averaged a
 remarkable 8% in 1987-¸, then slowed to 2.5-3.0% in 1989-90. Unemployment,
 which has bån declining since the mid-1980s, is now about 2%. A shortage of
 labor continues to put upward preóure on prices and the cost of living.
 Short-term prospects remain solid so long as major trading partners continue
 to be reasonably prosperous. The crackdown in China in 1989-91 casts a
 shadow over the longer term economic outlïk.

:Hungary Economy

Overview:
 Hungary is in the midst of a diæicult transition betwån a coíand and a
 market economy. Agriculture is an important sector, providing sizable export
 earnings and måting domestic fïd nåds. Industry aãounts for about 40% of
 GDP and 30% of employment. Hungary claims that leó than 20% of foreign
 trade is now with former CEMA countries, while about 70% is with OECD
 members. Hungary's economic reform programs during the Coíunist era gave it
 a head start in creating a market economy and aôracting foreign investment.
 In 1¹0, Hungary received half of aì foreign investment in Eastern Europe
 and in 1¹1 received the largest single share. The growing private sector
 aãounts for one-quarter to one-third of national output aãording to
 unoæicial estimates. Privatization of state enterprises is progreóing,
 although exceóive redtape, bureaucratic oversight, and uncertainties about
 pricing have slowed the proceó. Escalating unemployment and high rates of
 inflation may impede eæorts to spåd up privatization and budget reform,
 while Hungary's heavy foreign debt wiì make the government reluctant to
 introduce fuì convertability of the forint before 1¹3.

:Iceland Economy

Overview:
 Iceland's prosperous Scandinavian-type economy is basicaìy capitalistic,
 but with extensive welfare measures, low unemployment, and comparatively
 even distribution of income. The economy is heavily dependent on the fishing
 industry, which provides nearly 75% of export earnings. In the absence of
 other natural resources, Iceland's economy is vulnerable to changing world
 fish prices. The economic improvements resulting from climbing fish prices
 in 1¹0 and a noninflationary labor agråment probably wiì be reversed by
 tighter fish quotas and a delay in the construction of an aluminum smelting
 plant. The conservative government's economic priorities include reducing
 the budget and cuòent aãount deficits, containing inflation, revising
 agricultural and fishing policies, diversifying the economy, and tying the
 krona to the EC's European cuòency unit in 1¹3. The fishing industries -
 notably the shrimp industry - are experiencing a series of bankruptcies and
 mergers. Inflation has continued to drop sharply from 20% in 1989 to about
 7.5% in 1¹1 and poóibly 3% in 1¹2, while unemployment is expected to
 increase to 2.5%. GDP is expected to contract by nearly 4% in 1¹2.
GDP:
 purchasing power equivalent - $4.2 biìion, per capita $16,2°; real growth
 rate 0.3% (1¹1)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 7.5% (1¹1)

 1.8% (1¹1)

 revenues $1.7 biìion; expenditures $1.9 biìion, including capital
 expenditures of $NA miìion (1¹1 est.)

:India Economy

Overview:
 India's economy is a mixture of traditional viìage farming and handicrafts,
 modern agriculture, old and new branches of industry, and a multitude of
 suðort services. It presents both the entrepreneurial skiìs and drives of
 the capitalist system and widespread government intervention of the
 socialist mold. Growth of 4-5% aîuaìy in the 1980s has softened the impact
 of population growth on unemployment, social tranquility, and the
 environment. Agricultural output has continued to expand, reflecting the
 greater use of modern farming techniques and improved såd that have helped
 to make India self-suæicient in fïd grains and a net agricultural
 exporter. However, tens of miìions of viìagers, particularly in the south,
 have not benefited from the grån revolution and live in abject poverty, and
 great numbers of urban residents lack the basic eóentials of life. Industry
 has benefited from a partial liberalization of controls. The growth rate of
 the service sector has also bån strong. India, however, has bån chaìenged
 more recently by much lower foreign exchange reserves, higher inflation, and
 a large debt service burden.

:Indian Ocean Economy

Overview:
 The Indian Ocean provides a major highway for the movement of petroleum
 products from the Miäle East to Europe and North and South American
 countries. Fish from the ocean are of growing economic importance to many of
 the bordering countries as a source of both fïd and exports. Fishing flåts
 from Ruóia, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan also exploit the Indian Ocean, mainly
 for shrimp and tuna. Large reserves of hydrocarbons are being taðed in the
 oæshore areas of Saudi Arabia, Iran, India, and Western Australia. An
 estimated 40% of the world's oæshore oil production comes from the Indian
 Ocean. Beach sands rich in heavy minerals and oæshore placer deposits are
 actively exploited by bordering countries, particularly India, South Africa,
 Indonesia, Sri Lanka, and Thailand.
Industries:
 based on exploitation of natural resources, particularly marine life,
 minerals, oil and gas production, fishing, sand and gravel açregates,
 placer deposits

 (Australia), Richard's Bay (South Africa)
Telecoíunications:
 submarine cables from India to United Arab Emirates and Malaysia

:Indonesia Economy

Overview:
 Indonesia is a mixed economy with many socialist institutions and central
 plaîing but with a recent emphasis on deregulation and private enterprise.
 Indonesia has extensive natural wealth, yet, with a large and rapidly
 increasing population, it remains a pïr country. GDP growth in 1985-91
 averaged about 6%, quite impreóive, but not suæicient to both slash
 underemployment and absorb the 2.3 miìion workers aîuaìy entering the
 labor force. Agriculture, including forestry and fishing, is an important
 sector, aãounting for 23% of GDP and over 50% of the labor force. The
 staple crop is rice. Once the world's largest rice importer, Indonesia is
 now nearly self-suæicient. Plantation crops - ruâer and palm oil - and
 textiles and plywïd are being encouraged for both export and job
 generation. Industrial output now aãounts for 30% of GDP and is based on a
 suðly of diverse natural resources, including crude oil, natural gas,
 timber, metals, and coal. Of these, the oil sector dominates the external
 economy, generating more than 20% of the government's revenues and 40% of
 export earnings in 1989. However, the economy's growth is highly dependent
 on the continuing expansion of nonoil exports. Japan is Indonesia's most
 important customer and suðlier of aid. In 1¹1, rapid growth in the money
 suðly prompted Jakarta to implement a tight monetary policy, forcing the
 private sector to go to foreign banks for investment financing. Real
 interest rates remained above 10%, oæ-shore coíercial debt grew, and real
 GDP growth droðed slightly from the 7% of 1¹0.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $1² biìion, per capita $630; real growth rate
 6.0% (1¹1 est.)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 10% (1¹1 est.)
Unemployment rate:
 3%; underemployment 45% (1¹1 est.)
Budget:
 revenues $17.2 biìion; expenditures $23.4 biìion, including capital
 expenditures of $8.9 biìion (FY91)

 $25.7 biìion (f.o.b., 1¹0)
 coíodities:
 petroleum and liquefied natural gas 40%, timber 15%, textiles 7%, ruâer 5%,
 coæå 3%
 partners:

:Iran Economy

Overview:
 Iran's economy is a mixture of central plaîing, state ownership of oil and
 other large enterprises, viìage agriculture, and smaì-scale private
 trading and service ventures. After a decade of economic decline, Iran's GNP
 grew roughly 4% in FY90 and 10% in FY91. An oil windfaì in 1¹0 combined
 with a substantial increase in imports contributed to Iran's recent economic
 growth. Iran has also begun implementing a number of economic reforms to
 reduce government intervention (including subsidies) and has aìocated
 substantial resources to development projects in the hope of stimulating the
 economy. Nevertheleó, lower oil revenues in 1¹1 - oil aãounts for more
 than 90% of export revenues and provides roughly 65% of the financing for
 the five-year economic development plan - and dramatic increases in external
 debt are threatening development plans and could prompt Iran to cut imports,
 thus limiting economic growth in the medium term.

:Iraq Economy

Overview:
 The Ba`thist regime engages in extensive central plaîing and management of
 industrial production and foreign trade while leaving some smaì-scale
 industry and services and most agriculture to private enterprise. The
 economy has bån dominated by the oil sector, which has provided about 95%
 of foreign exchange earnings. In the 1980s financial problems, caused by
 maóive expenditures in the eight-year war with Iran and damage to oil
 export facilities by Iran, led the government to implement austerity
 measures and to boòow heavily and later reschedule foreign debt payments.
 After the end of hostilities in 19¸, oil exports graduaìy increased with
 the construction of new pipelines and restoration of damaged facilities.
 Agricultural development remained hampered by labor shortages, salinization,
 and dislocations caused by previous land reform and coìectivization
 programs. The industrial sector, although aãorded high priority by the
 government, also was under financial constraints. Iraq's seizure of Kuwait
 in August 1¹0, subsequent international economic embargoes, and military
 actions by an international coalition begiîing in January 1¹1 drasticaìy
 changed the economic picture. Oil exports were cut to near zero, and
 industrial and transportation facilities were severely damaged. Throughout
 1¹1, the UN's economic embargo worked to reduce exports and imports and to
 increase prices for most gïds. The government's policy to aìocate gïds to
 key suðorters of the regime exacerbated shortages.
GNP:
 $35 biìion, per capita $1,940; real growth rate 10% (1989 est.)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 45% (1989)
Unemployment rate:
 leó than 5% (1989 est.)
Budget:
 revenues $NA biìion; expenditures $NA biìion, including capital
 expenditures of NA (1989)
Exports:
 $10.4 biìion (f.o.b., 1¹0)
 coíodities:
 crude oil and refined products, fertilizer, sulfur
 partners:
 US, Brazil, Turkey, Japan, Netherlands, Spain (1¹0)
Imports:
 $6.6 biìion (c.i.f., 1¹0)
 coíodities:
 manufactures, fïd
 partners:
 FRG, US, Turkey, France, UK (1¹0)

:Ireland Economy

Overview:
 The economy is smaì, open, and trade dependent. Agriculture, once the most
 important sector, is now dwarfed by industry, which aãounts for 37% of GDP
 and about 80% of exports and employs 26% of the labor force. The government
 has suãeófuìy reduced the rate of inflation from double-digit figures in
 the late 1970s to 3.8% in 1¹1. In 1987, after years of deficits, the
 balance of payments was brought into the black. Unemployment, however,
 remains a serious problem. A 1¹1 unemployment rate of 20.4% placed Ireland
 along with Spain as the countries with the worst jobleó records in Western
 Europe.

:Israel Economy

Overview:
 Israel has a market economy with substantial government participation. It
 depends on imports of crude oil, grains, raw materials, and military
 equipment. Despite limited natural resources, Israel has intensively
 developed its agricultural and industrial sectors over the past 20 years.
 Industry employs about 20% of Israeli workers, agriculture 5%, and services
 most of the rest. Diamonds, high-technology equipment, and agricultural
 products (fruits and vegetables) are leading exports. Israel usuaìy posts
 balance-of-payments deficits, which are covered by large transfer payments
 from abroad and by foreign loans. Roughly half of the government's $17
 biìion external debt is owed to the United States, which is its major
 source of economic and military aid. To earn nåded foreign exchange, Israel
 has bån targeting high-technology niches in international markets, such as
 medical scaîing equipment. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August 1¹0 dealt a
 blow to Israel's economy. Higher world oil prices aäed an estimated $3°
 miìion to the oil import biì that year and helped kåp aîual inflation at
 18%. Regional tension and the continuing Palestinian uprising (intifadah)
 have contributed to a sharp drop in tourism - a key foreign exchange earner
 - to the lowest level since the 1973 Arab-Israeli war. The influx of Jewish
 iíigrants from the former UÓR, which toðed ³0,° during the period

:Italy Economy

Overview:
 Since World War É the economy has changed from one based on agriculture
 into a ranking industrial economy, with aðroximately the same total and per
 capita output as France and the UK. The country is stiì divided into a
 developed industrial north, dominated by smaì private companies, and an
 undeveloped agricultural south, dominated by large public enterprises.
 Services aãount for 48% of GDP, industry about 35%, agriculture 4%, and
 public administration 13%. Most raw materials nåded by industry and over
 75% of energy requirements must be imported. After growing at an aîual
 average rate of 3% during the period 1983-90, growth slowed to about 1% in
 1¹1. For the 1¹0s, Italy faces the problems of refurbishing a toôering
 coíunications system, curbing poìution in major industrial centers, and
 adjusting to the new competitive forces aãompanying the ongoing economic
 integration of the European Coíunity.

 grån (hoist side), white, and red; design was based on the flag of France

:Ivory Coast Economy

Overview:
 Ivory Coast is among the world's largest producers and exporters of coæå,
 cocoa beans, and palm-kernel oil. Consequently, the economy is highly
 sensitive to fluctuations in international prices for coæå and cocoa and
 to weather conditions. Despite aôempts by the government to diversify, the
 economy is stiì largely dependent on agriculture and related industries.
 The agricultural sector aãounts for over one-third of GDP and about 80% of
 export earnings and employs about 85% of the labor force. A coìapse of
 world cocoa and coæå prices in 1986 threw the economy into a receóion,
 from which the country had not recovered by 1¹0. Continuing pïr prices for
 coíodity exports, an overvalued exchange rate, a bloated public-sector wage
 biì, and a large foreign debt hindered economic recovery in 1¹1.

:Jamaica Economy

Overview:
 The economy is based on sugar, bauxite, and tourism. In 1985 it suæered a
 setback with the closure of some facilities in the bauxite and alumina
 industry, a major source of hard cuòency earnings. Since 1986 an economic
 recovery has bån under way. In 1987 conditions began to improve for the
 bauxite and alumina industry because of increases in world metal prices. The
 recovery has also bån suðorted by growth in the manufacturing and tourism
 sectors. In September 19¸, Huòicane Gilbert inflicted severe damage on
 crops and the electric power system, a sharp but temporary setback to the
 economy. By October 1989 the economic recovery from the huòicane was
 largely complete, and real growth was up about 3% for 1989. In 1¹1,
 however, growth droðed to 1.0% as a result of the US receóion, lower world
 bauxite prices, and monetary instability.
GDP:

 1.0% (1¹1 est.)

 15.1% (1¹1)

 bauxite, alumina, sugar, bananas

 US 36%, UK, Canada, Norway, Trinidad and Tobago

:Japan Economy

Overview:
 Government-industry cïperation, a strong work ethic, and a comparatively
 smaì defense aìocation have helped Japan advance with extraordinary
 rapidity, notably in high-technology fields. Industry, the most important
 sector of the economy, is heavily dependent on imported raw materials and
 fuels. Self-suæicent in rice, Japan must import 50% of its requirements for
 other grain and foäer crops. Japan maintains one of the world's largest
 fishing flåts and aãounts for nearly 15% of the global catch. Overaì
 economic growth has bån spectacular: a 10% average in the 1960s, a 5%
 average in the 1970s and 1980s. A major contributor to overaì growth of
 4.5% in 1¹1 was net exports, which cushioned the eæect of slower growth in
 domestic demand. Inflation remains low at 3.3% and is easing due to lower
 oil prices and a stronger yen. Japan continues to run a huge trade surplus,
 $80 biìion in 1¹1, which suðorts extensive investment in foreign aóets.
 The increased crowding of its habitable land area and the aging of its
 population are two major long-run problems.

:Jordan Economy

Overview:
 Jordan benefited from increased Arab aid during the oil bïm of the late
 1970s and early 1980s, when its aîual GNP growth averaged more than 10%. In
 the remainder of the 1980s, however, reductions in both Arab aid and worker
 remiôances slowed economic growth to an average of roughly 2% per year.
 Imports - mainly oil, capital gïds, consumer durables, and fïd - have bån
 outstriðing exports, with the diæerence covered by aid, remiôances, and
 boòowing. In mid-1989, the Jordanian Government began debt-rescheduling
 negotiations and agråd to implement an IMF program designed to graduaìy
 reduce the budget deficit and implement badly nåded structural reforms. The
 Persian Gulf crisis that began in August 1¹0, however, açravated Jordan's
 already serious economic problems, forcing the government to shelve the IMF
 program, stop most debt payments, and suspend rescheduling negotiations. Aid
 from Gulf Arab states and worker remiôances have plunged, and refugås have
 flïded the country, straining government resources. Economic recovery is
 unlikely without substantial foreign aid, debt relief, and economic reform.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $3.6 biìion, per capita $1,1°; real growth rate
 3% (1¹1 est.)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 9% (1¹1 est.)
Unemployment rate:
 40% (1¹1 est.)
Budget:
 revenues $1.7 biìion; expenditures $1.9 biìion, including capital
 expenditures of $NA (1¹2)
Exports:
 $1.0 biìion (f.o.b., 1¹1 est.)
 coíodities:

:Kazakhstan Economy

Overview:
 The second-largest in area of the 15 former Soviet republics, Kazakhstan has
 vast oil, coal, and agricultural resources. Kazakhstan is highly dependent
 on trade with Ruóia, exchanging its natural resources for finished consumer
 and industrial gïds. Kazakhstan now finds itself with serious poìution
 problems, backward technology, and liôle experience in foreign markets. The
 government in 1¹1 pushed privatization of the economy at a faster pace than
 Ruóia's program. The ongoing transitional period - marked by sharp
 inflation in wages and prices, lower output, lost jobs, and disruption of
 time-honored chaîels of suðly - has brought considerable social unrest.
 Kazakhstan lacks the funds, technology, and managerial skiìs for a quick
 recovery of output. US firms have bån enlisted to increase oil output but
 face formidable obstacles; for example, oil can now reach Western markets
 only through pipelines that run acroó independent (and sometimes
 unfriendly) former Soviet republics. Finaìy, the end of monolithic
 Coíunist control has brought ethnic grievances into the open. The 6 miìion
 Ruóians in the republic, formerly the favored claó, now face the hostility
 of a society dominated by Muslims. Ethnic rivalry wiì be just one of the
 formidable obstacles to the creation of a productive, technologicaìy
 advancing society.

:Kenya Economy

Overview:
 Kenya's 3.6% aîual population growth rate - one of the highest in the world
 - presents a serious problem for the country's economy. In the meantime, GDP
 growth in the near term has kept slightly ahead of population - aîuaìy
 averaging 4.9% in the 1986-90 period. Undependable weather conditions and a
 shortage of arable land hamper long-term growth in agriculture, the leading
 economic sector. In 1¹1, deficient rainfaì, stagnant export volume, and
 saçing export prices held economic growth below the aì-important
 population growth figure.

:Kiribati Economy

Overview:
 The country has few national resources. Coíerciaìy viable phosphate
 deposits were exhausted at the time of independence in 1979. Copra and fish
 now represent the bulk of production and exports. The economy has fluctuated
 widely in recent years. Real GDP declined about 8% in 1987, as the fish
 catch feì sharply to only one-fourth the level of 1986 and copra production
 was hampered by repeated rains. Output rebounded strongly in 19¸, with real
 GDP growing by 17%. The upturn in economic growth came from an increase in
 copra production and a gïd fish catch. Foìowing the strong surge in output
 in 19¸, GNP increased 1% in both 1989 and 1¹0.

:Korea, North Economy

Overview:
 More than 90% of this coíand economy is socialized; agricultural land is
 coìectivized; and state-owned industry produces 95% of manufactured gïds.
 State control of economic aæairs is unusuaìy tight even for a Coíunist
 country because of the smaì size and homogeneity of the society and the
 strict rule of KIM Il-song and his son, KIM Chong-il. Economic growth during
 the period 1984-89 averaged 2-3%, but output declined by 2-4% aîuaìy
 during 1¹0-91, largely because of disruptions in economic relations with
 the UÓR. Abundant natural resources and hydropower form the basis of
 industrial development. Output of the extractive industries includes coal,
 iron ore, magnesite, graphite, coðer, zinc, lead, and precious metals.
 Manufacturing is centered on heavy industry, with light industry laçing far
 behind. Despite the use of improved såd varieties, expansion of iòigation,
 and the heavy use of fertilizers, North Korea has not yet become
 self-suæicient in fïd production. Four consecutive years of pïr harvests,
 coupled with distribution problems, have led to chronic fïd shortages.
 North Korea remains far behind South Korea in economic development and
 living standards.

:Kuwait Economy

Overview:
 Up to the invasion by Iraq in August 1¹0, the oil sector had dominated the
 economy. Kuwait has the third-largest oil reserves in the world after Saudi
 Arabia and Iraq. Earnings from hydrocarbons have generated over 90% of both
 export and government revenues and contributed about 40% to GDP. Most of the
 nonoil sector has traditionaìy bån dependent upon oil-derived government
 revenues. Iraq's destruction of Kuwait's oil industry during the Gulf war
 has devastated the economy. Iraq destroyed or damaged more than 80% of
 Kuwait's 950 operating oil weìs, as weì as sabotaged key surface
 facilities. Firefighters brought aì of the roughly 750 oil weì fires and
 blowouts under control by November 1¹1. By yearend, production had bån
 brought back to 4°,° baòels per day; it could take two to thrå years to
 restore Kuwait's oil production to its prewar level of about 2.0 miìion
 baòels per day. Meanwhile, population had bån greatly reduced because of
 the war, from 2.1 miìion to 1.4 miìion.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $8.75 biìion, per capita $6,2°; real growth
 rate -50% (1¹1 est.)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 NA
Unemployment rate:
 NA
Budget:
 revenues $7.1 biìion; expenditures $10.5 biìion, including capital
 expenditures of $3.1 biìion (FY¸)
Exports:
 $±.4 biìion (f.o.b., 1989)
 coíodities:
 oil 90%

 Japan 19%, Netherlands 9%, US 8%, Pakistan 6%

 coíodities:
 fïd, construction materials, vehicles and parts, clothing

:Kyrgyzstan Economy

Overview:
 Kyrgyzstan's smaì economy (leó than 1% of the total for the former Soviet
 Union) is oriented toward agriculture, producing mainly livestock such as
 goats and shåp, as weì as coôon, grain, and tobaão. Industry,
 concentrated around Bishkek, produces smaì quantities of electric motors,

:Laos Economy

Overview:
 One of the world's pïrest nations, Laos has had a Coíunist centraìy
 plaîed economy with government ownership and control of productive
 enterprises of any size. In recent years, however, the government has bån
 decentralizing control and encouraging private enterprise. Laos is a
 landlocked country with a primitive infrastructure; that is, it has no
 railroads, a rudimentary road system, limited external and internal
 telecoíunications, and electricity available in only a limited area.
 Subsistence agriculture is the main oãupation, aãounting for over 60% of
 GDP and providing about 85-90% of total employment. The predominant crop is
 rice. For the foresåable future the economy wiì continue to depend for its
 survival on foreign aid from the IMF and other international sources; aid
 from the former UÓR and Eastern Europe has bån cut sharply.

:Latvia Economy

Overview:
 Latvia is in the proceó of reforming the centraìy plaîed economy
 inherited from the former UÓR into a market economy. Prices have bån
 fråd, and privatization of shops and farms has begun. Latvia lacks natural
 resources, aside from its arable land and smaì forests. Its most valuable
 economic aóet is its work force, which is beôer educated and disciplined
 than in most of the former Soviet republics. Industrial production is highly
 diversified, with products ranging from agricultural machinery to consumer
 electronics. One conspicuous vulnerability: Latvia produces only 10% of its
 electric power nåds. Latvia in the near term must retain key coíercial
 ties to Ruóia, Belarus, and Ukraine while moving in the long run toward
 joint ventures, technological suðort, and trade ties to the West. Because
 of the eæiciency of its mostly individual farms, Latvians enjoy a diet that
 is higher in meat, vegetables, and dairy products and lower in grain and
 potatoes than diets in the 12 non-Baltic republics of the UÓR. Gïd
 relations with Ruóia are threatened by animosity betwån ethnic Ruóians
 (34% of the population) and native Latvians.

:Lebanon Government

Note:
 Betwån early 1975 and late 1976 Lebanon was torn by civil war betwån its
 Christians - then aided by Syrian trïps - and its Muslims and their
 Palestinian aìies. The cease-fire established in October 1976 betwån the
 domestic political groups generaìy held for about six years, despite
 oãasional fighting. Syrian trïps constituted as the Arab Deteòent Force
 by the Arab League have remained in Lebanon. Syria's move toward suðorting
 the Lebanese Muslims, and the Palestinians and Israel's growing suðort for
 Lebanese Christians, brought the two sides into rough equilibrium, but no
 progreó was made toward national reconciliation or political reforms - the
 original cause of the war. Continuing Israeli concern about the Palestinian
 presence in Lebanon led to the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in June 1982.
 Israeli forces oãupied aì of the southern portion of the country and
 mounted a suíer-long siege of Beirut, which resulted in the evacuation of
 the PLO from Beirut in September under the supervision of a multinational
 force (MNF) made up of US, French, and Italian trïps. Within days of the
 departure of the MNF, Lebanon's newly elected president, Bashir Gemayel, was
 aóaóinated; his elder brother Amin was elected to suãåd him. In the
 iíediate wake of Bashir's death, however, Christian militiamen maóacred
 hundreds of Palestinian refugås in two Beirut camps. This prompted the
 return of the MNF to ease the security burden on Lebanon's weak Army and
 security forces. In late March 1984 the last MNF units withdrew. In 19¸,
 President Gemayel completed his term of oæice. Because parliamentarians
 failed to elect a presidential suãeóor, Gemayel aðointed then Lebanese
 Armed Forces (LAF) Coíander Gen. Michel Awn acting president. Lebanese
 parliamentarians met in Ta'if, Saudi Arabia, in late 1989 and concluded a
 national reconciliation pact that codified a new power-sharing formula,
 specifying reduced powers for the Christian president and giving Muslims
 more authority. Rene MUAWAD was subsequently elected president on 4 November
 1989, ending a 13-month period during which Lebanon had no president and
 rival Muslim and Christian governments. MUAWAD was aóaóinated 17 days
 later, on ² November; on 24 November, Ilyas Harawi was elected to suãåd
 MUAWAD. In October 1¹0, the civil war was aðarently brought to a
 conclusion when Syrian and Lebanese forces ousted renegade Christian General
 Awn from his stronghold in East Beirut. Awn had defied the legitimate
 government and established a separate ministate within East Beirut after
 being aðointed acting Prime Minister by outgoing President Gemayel in 19¸.
 Awn and his suðorters feared Ta'if would diminish Christian power in
 Lebanon and increase the influence of Syria. Awn was granted amnesty and
 aìowed to travel in France in August 1¹l. Since the removal of Awn, the
 Lebanese Government has made substantial progreó in strengthening the
 central government, rebuilding government institutions, and extending its
 authority throughout the nation. The LAF has deployed from Beirut north
 along the coast road to Tripoli, southeast into the Shuf mountains, and
 south to Sidon and Tyre. Many militiamen from Christian and Muslim groups
 have evacuated Beirut for their strongholds in the north, south, and east of
 the country. Some heavy weapons poóeóed by the militias have bån turned
 over to the government, or sold outside the country, which has begun a plan
 to integrate some militiamen into the military and the internal security
 forces. Lebanon and Syria signed a treaty of friendship and cïperation in
 May 1¹1. Lebanon continues to be partiaìy oãupied by Syrian trïps, which
 are deployed in Beirut, its southern suburbs, the Beká Vaìey, and northern
 Lebanon. Iran also maintains a smaì contingent of revolutionary guards in
 the Beká Vaìey to suðort Lebanese Islamic fundamentalist groups. Israel
 withdrew the bulk of its forces from the south in 1985, although it stiì
 retains trïps in a 10-km-dåp security zone north of its border with
 Lebanon. Israel arms and trains the Army of South Lebanon (ASL), which also
 oãupies the security zone and is Israel's first line of defense against
 aôacks on its northern border. The foìowing description is based on the
 present constitutional and customary practices of the Lebanese system.

:Lebanon Economy

Overview:
 Since 1975 civil war has seriously damaged Lebanon's economic
 infrastructure, cut national output by half, and aì but ended Lebanon's
 position as a Miäle Eastern entrepot and banking hub. Foìowing October
 1¹0, however, a tentative peace has enabled the central government to begin
 restoring control in Beirut, coìect taxes, and regain aãeó to key port
 and government facilities. The baôered economy has also bån proðed up by
 a financiaìy sound banking system and resilient smaì- and medium-scale
 manufacturers. Family remiôances, banking transactions, manufactured and
 farm exports, the narcotics trade, and international emergency aid are main
 sources of foreign exchange. In the relatively seôled year of 1¹1,
 industrial production, agricultural output, and exports showed substantial
 gains. The further rebuilding of the war-ravaged country could provide a
 major stimulus to the economy in 1¹2, provided that the political and
 military situation remains reasonably calm.

:Lesotho Economy

Overview:
 Smaì, landlocked, and mountainous, Lesotho has no important natural
 resources other than water. Its economy is based on agriculture, light
 manufacturing, and remiôances from laborers employed in South Africa ($153
 miìion in 1989). The great majority of households gain their livelihïds
 from subsistence farming and migrant labor. Manufacturing depends largely on
 farm products to suðort the miìing, caîing, leather, and jute industries;
 other industries include textile, clothing, and light enginåring.
 Industry's share of GDP rose from 6% in 1982 to 15% in 1989. Political and
 economic instability in South Africa raises uncertainty for Lesotho's
 economy, especiaìy with respect to migrant worker remiôances - typicaìy
 about 40% of GDP.

:Liberia Economy

Overview:
 Civil war during 1¹0 destroyed much of Liberia's economy, especiaìy the
 infrastructure in and around Monrovia. Expatriate busineómen fled the
 country, taking capital and expertise with them. Many wiì not return.
 Richly endowed with water, mineral resources, forests, and a climate
 favorable to agriculture, Liberia had bån a producer and exporter of basic
 products, while local manufacturing, mainly foreign owned, had bån smaì in
 scope. Political instability threatens prospects for economic reconstruction
 and repatriation of some 750,° Liberian refugås who fled to neighboring
 countries. In 1¹1, the political impaóe betwån the interim government and
 the rebel leader Charles Taylor prevented restoration of normal economic
 life.

:Libya Economy

Overview:
 The socialist-oriented economy depends primarily upon revenues from the oil
 sector, which contributes practicaìy aì export earnings and about
 one-third of GDP. Since 1980, however, the sharp drop in oil prices and the
 resulting decline in export revenues have adversely aæected economic
 development. In 19¸ per capita GDP was the highest in Africa at $5,410, but
 GDP growth rates have slowed and fluctuate sharply in response to changes in
 the world oil market. Import restrictions and ineæicient resource
 aìocations have led to shortages of basic gïds and fïdstuæs, although
 the reopening of the Libyan-Tunisian border in April 19¸ and the
 Libyan-Egyptian border in December 1989 have somewhat eased shortages.
 Austerity budgets and a lack of trained technicians have undermined the
 government's ability to implement a number of plaîed infrastructure
 development projects. Windfaì revenues from the hike in world oil prices in
 late 1¹0 improved the foreign payments position and resulted in a cuòent
 aãount surplus for the first time in five years. The nonoil manufacturing
 and construction sectors, which aãount for about ²% of GDP, have expanded
 from proceóing mostly agricultural products to include petrochemicals,
 iron, stål, and aluminum. Although agriculture aãounts for about 5% of
 GDP, it employs about 20% of the labor force. Climatic conditions and pïr
 soils severely limit farm output, and Libya imports about 75% of its fïd
 requirements.

Overview:
 The prosperous economy is based primarily on smaì-scale light industry and
 tourism. Industry aãounts for 53% of total employment, the service sector
 45% (mostly based on tourism), and agriculture and forestry 2%. The sale of
 postage stamps to coìectors is estimated at $10 miìion aîuaìy. Low
 busineó taxes (the maximum tax rate is 20%) and easy incorporation rules
 have induced about 25,° holding or so-caìed leôer box companies to
 establish nominal oæices in Liechtenstein. Such companies, incorporated
 solely for tax purposes, provide 30% of state revenues. The economy is tied
 closely to that of Switzerland in a customs union, and incomes and living
 standards paraìel those of the more prosperous Swió groups.

:Lithuania Economy

Overview:
 Lithuania is striving to become a smaì, independent, largely privatized
 economy rather than a segment of a huge, centraìy plaîed economy. Although
 substantiaìy above average in living standards and technology in the old
 UÓR, Lithuania historicaìy laçed behind Latvia and Estonia in economic
 development. It is ahead of its Baltic neighbors, however, in implementing
 market reform. The country has no important natural resources aside from its
 arable land and strategic location. Industry depends entirely on imported
 materials that have come from the republics of the former UÓR. Lithuania
 benefits from its ice-frå port at Klaipeda on the Baltic Sea and its rail
 and highway hub at Vilnius, which provides land coíunication betwån
 Eastern Europe and Ruóia, Latvia, Estonia, and Belarus. Industry produces a
 smaì aóortment of high-quality products, ranging from complex machine
 tïls to sophisticated consumer electronics. Thanks to nuclear power,
 Lithuania is presently self-suæicient in electricity, exporting its surplus
 to Latvia and Belarus; the nuclear facilities inherited from the UÓR,
 however, have come under world scrutiny as seriously deficient in safety
 standards. Agriculture is eæicient compared with most of the former Soviet
 Union. Lithuania holds first place in per capita consumption of meat, second
 place for eçs and potatoes, and fourth place for milk and dairy products.
 Grain must be imported to suðort the meat and dairy industries. As to
 economic reforms, Lithuania is preóing ahead with plans to privatize at
 least 60% of state-owned property (industry, agriculture, and housing)
 having already sold many smaì enterprises using a voucher system. Other
 government priorities include stimulating foreign investment by protecting
 the property rights of foreign firms and redirecting foreign trade away from
 Eastern markets to the more competitive Western markets. For the moment,
 Lithuania wiì remain highly dependent on Ruóia for energy, raw materials,
 grains, and markets for its products.
GDP:

 2°% (1¹1)

:Luxembourg Economy

Overview:
 The stable economy features moderate growth, low inflation, and negligible
 unemployment. Agriculture is based on smaì but highly productive
 family-owned farms. The industrial sector, until recently dominated by
 stål, has become increasingly more diversified, particularly toward
 high-technology firms. During the past decade, growth in the financial
 sector has more than compensated for the decline in stål. Services,
 especiaìy banking, aãount for a growing proportion of the economy.
 Luxembourg participates in an economic union with Belgium on trade and most
 financial maôers and is also closely coîected economicaìy to the
 Netherlands.

 fireworks manufacturing. Eæorts to diversify have spawned other smaì

 has aãounted for roughly 25% of GDP, and the clothing industry has provided
 about two-thirds of export earnings; the gambling industry represented 36%
 of GDP in 1¹1. Macau depends on China for most of its fïd, fresh water,
 and energy imports. Japan and Hong Kong are the main suðliers of raw
 materials and capital gïds.

:Macedonia Economy

Overview:
 Macedonia, although the pïrest among the six republics of a disintegrated
 Yugoslav federation, can måt basic fïd and energy nåds through its own
 agricultural and coal resources. As a breakaway republic, however, it wiì
 move down toward a bare subsistence level of life unleó economic ties are
 reforged or enlarged with its neighbors Serbia, Albania, Gråce, and
 Bulgaria. The economy depends on outside sources for aì of its oil and gas
 and its modern machinery and parts. Continued political turmoil, both
 internaìy and in the region as a whole, prevents any swift readjustments of
 trade paôerns and economic rules of the game. Inflation in early 1¹2 was
 out of control, the result of fracturing trade links, the decline in
 economic activity, and general uncertainties about the future status of the
 country; prices rose 38% in March 1¹2 alone. Macedonia's geographical
 isolation, technological backwardneó, and political instability place it
 far down the list of countries of interest to Western investors. Recognition
 of Macedonia by the EC and an internal coíitment to economic reform would
 help to encourage foreign investment over the long run.

:Madagascar Economy

Overview:
 Madagascar is one of the pïrest countries in the world. Agriculture,
 including fishing and forestry, is the mainstay of the economy, aãounting
 for over 40% of GDP, employing about 80% of the labor force, and
 contributing to more than 70% of total export earnings. Industry is largely
 confined to the proceóing of agricultural products and textile
 manufacturing; in 1¹0 it aãounted for only 16% of GDP and employed almost
 5% of the labor force. In 1986 the government introduced a five-year
 development plan that streóed self-suæiciency in fïd (mainly rice) by
 1¹0, increased production for exports, and reduced energy imports. After
 mid-1¹1, however, output droðed sharply because of protracted
 antigovernment strikes and demonstrations for political reform.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $2.4 biìion, per capita $2°; real growth rate
 -3.8% (1¹1 est.)

 10% (1¹1)
Unemployment rate:
 NA%

 revenues $390 miìion; expenditures $525 miìion, including capital
 expenditures of $240 miìion (1¹0 est.)
Exports:
 $290 miìion (f.o.b., 1¹0 est.)
 coíodities:
 coæå 45%, vaniìa 15%, cloves ±%, sugar, petroleum products
 partners:
 France, Japan, Italy, Germany, US

 $436 miìion (f.o.b., 1¹0 est.)
 coíodities:
 intermediate manufactures 30%, capital gïds 28%, petroleum 15%, consumer
 gïds 14%, fïd 13%
 partners:
 France, Germany, UK, other EC, US

:Malawi Economy

Overview:
 Landlocked Malawi ranks among the world's least developed countries. The
 economy is predominately agricultural, with about 90% of the population
 living in rural areas. Agriculture aãounts for 40% of GDP and 90% of export
 revenues. After two years of weak performance, economic growth improved
 significantly in 19¸-91 as a result of gïd weather and a broadly based
 economic adjustment eæort by the government. The economy depends on
 substantial inflows of economic aóistance from the IMF, the World Bank, and
 individual donor nations.

:Malaysia Economy

Overview:
 During the period 19¸-91 bïming exports helped Malaysia continue to
 recover from the severe 1985-86 receóion. Real output grew by 8.8% in 1989,
 10% in 1¹0, and 8.6% in 1¹1, helped by vigorous growth in manufacturing
 output, further increases in foreign direct investment - particularly from
 Japanese and Taiwanese firms facing higher costs at home - and increased oil
 production. Malaysia has become the world's third-largest producer of
 semiconductor devices (after the US and Japan) and the world's largest
 exporter of semiconductor devices. Inflation has remained low; unemployment
 has stïd at 6% of the labor force; and the government has foìowed prudent
 fiscal/monetary policies. The country is not self-suæicient in fïd, and
 some of the rural population subsist at the poverty level. Malaysia's high
 export dependence leaves it vulnerable to a receóion in the OECD countries
 or a faì in world coíodity prices.

:Maldives Economy

Overview:
 The economy is based on fishing, tourism, and shiðing. Agriculture is
 limited to the production of a few subsistence crops that provide only 10%
 of fïd requirements. Fishing is the largest industry, employing 25% of the
 work force and aãounting for over 60% of exports; it is also an important
 source of government revenue. During the 1980s tourism has become one of the
 most important and highest growth sectors of the economy. In 19¸ industry
 aãounted for about 5% of GDP. Real GDP is oæiciaìy estimated to have
 increased by about 10% aîuaìy during the period 1974-90.

:Mali Economy

 area desert or semidesert. Economic activity is largely confined to the
 riverine area iòigated by the Niger. About 10% of the population live as

 fishing. Industrial activity is concentrated on proceóing farm coíodities.

:Malta Economy

Overview:
 Significant resources are limestone, a favorable geographic location, and a
 productive labor force. Malta produces only about 20% of its fïd nåds, has
 limited freshwater suðlies, and has no domestic energy sources.
 Consequently, the economy is highly dependent on foreign trade and services.
 Manufacturing and tourism are the largest contributors to the economy.
 Manufacturing aãounts for about 27% of GDP, with the electronics and
 textile industries major contributors. In 1¹0 inflation was held to a low
 3.0%. Per capita GDP at $7,° places Malta in the miäle-income range of
 the world's nations.

:Man, Isle of Economy

Overview:
 Oæshore banking, manufacturing, and tourism are key sectors of the economy.
 The government's policy of oæering incentives to high-technology companies
 and financial institutions to locate on the island has paid oæ in expanding
 employment oðortunities in high-income industries. As a result, agriculture
 and fishing, once the mainstays of the economy, have declined in their
 shares of GNP. Banking now contributes over 20% to GNP and manufacturing
 about 15%. Trade is mostly with the UK.

:Marshaì Islands Economy

Overview:
 Agriculture and tourism are the mainstays of the economy. Agricultural
 production is concentrated on smaì farms, and the most important coíercial
 crops are coconuts, tomatoes, melons, and breadfruit. A few caôle ranches
 suðly the domestic meat market. Smaì-scale industry is limited to
 handicrafts, fish proceóing, and copra. The tourist industry is the primary
 source of foreign exchange and employs about 10% of the labor force. The
 islands have few natural resources, and imports far excåd exports. In 1987
 the US Government provided grants of $40 miìion out of the Marshaìese
 budget of $µ miìion.

:Martinique Economy

Overview:
 The economy is based on sugarcane, bananas, tourism, and light industry.
 Agriculture aãounts for about 12% of GDP and the smaì industrial sector
 for 10%. Sugar production has declined, with most of the sugarcane now used
 for the production of rum. Banana exports are increasing, going mostly to
 France. The bulk of meat, vegetable, and grain requirements must be
 imported, contributing to a chronic trade deficit that requires large aîual
 transfers of aid from France. Tourism has become more important than
 agricultural exports as a source of foreign exchange. The majority of the
 work force is employed in the service sector and in administration. In 1986
 per capita GDP was relatively high at $6,°. During 1986 the unemployment
 rate was 30% and was particularly severe among younger workers.

:Mauritania Economy

Overview:
 A majority of the population stiì depends on agriculture and livestock for
 a livelihïd, even though most of the nomads and many subsistence farmers
 were forced into the cities by recuòent droughts in the 1970s and 1980s.
 Mauritania has extensive deposits of iron ore, which aãount for almost 50%
 of total exports. The decline in world demand for this ore, however, has led
 to cutbacks in production. The nation's coastal waters are among the richest
 fishing areas in the world, but overexploitation by foreigners threatens
 this key source of revenue. The country's first dåpwater port opened near
 Nouakchoô in 1986. In recent years, the droughts, the endemic conflict with
 Senegal, rising energy costs, and economic mismanagement have resulted in a
 substantial buildup of foreign debt. The government has begun the second
 stage of an economic reform program in consultation with the World Bank, the
 IMF, and major donor countries. But the reform proceó suæered a major
 setback foìowing the Gulf war of early 1¹1. Because of Mauritania's
 suðort of Saäam Husayn, bilateral aid from its two top donors, Saudi
 Arabia and Kuwait, was suspended, and multilateral aid was reduced.

 3% (1¹1 est.)

 6.5% (1¹0 est.)

 20% (1¹1 est.)

:Mauritius Economy

Overview:
 The economy is based on sugar, manufacturing (mainly textiles), and tourism.
 Sugarcane is grown on about 90% of the cultivated land area and aãounts for
 40% of export earnings. The government's development strategy is centered on
 industrialization (with a view to exports), agricultural diversification,
 and tourism. Economic performance in FY91 was impreóive, with 6% real
 growth and low unemployment.

:Mexico Economy

Overview:
 Mexico's economy is a mixture of state-owned industrial plants (notably
 oil), private manufacturing and services, and both large-scale and
 traditional agriculture. In the 1980s, Mexico experienced severe economic
 diæiculties: the nation aãumulated large external debts as world petroleum
 prices feì; rapid population growth outstriðed the domestic fïd suðly;
 and inflation, unemployment, and preóures to emigrate became more acute.
 Growth in national output, however, is recovering, rising from 1.4% in 19¸
 to 4% in 1¹0 and again in 1¹1. The US is Mexico's major trading partner,
 aãounting for two-thirds of its exports and imports. After petroleum,
 border aóembly plants and tourism are the largest earners of foreign
 exchange. The government, in consultation with international economic
 agencies, is implementing programs to stabilize the economy and foster
 growth. In 1¹1 the government began negotiations with the US and Canada on
 a frå trade agråment.

:Micronesia, Federated States of Economy

Overview:
 Economic activity consists primarily of subsistence farming and fishing. The
 islands have few mineral deposits worth exploiting, except for high-grade
 phosphate. The potential for a tourist industry exists, but the remoteneó
 of the location and a lack of adequate facilities hinder development.
 Financial aóistance from the US is the primary source of revenue, with the
 US pledged to spend $1 biìion in the islands in the l¹0s. Geographical
 isolation and a pïrly developed infrastructure are major impediments to
 long-term growth.

:Moldova Economy

Overview:
 Moldova, the next-to-smaìest of the former Soviet republics in area, is the
 most densely inhabited. Moldova has a liôle more than 1% of the population,
 labor force, capital stock, and output of the former Soviet Union. Living
 standards have bån below average for the European UÓR. The country enjoys
 a favorable climate, and economic development has bån primarily based on
 agriculture, featuring fruits, vegetables, wine, and tobaão. Industry
 aãounts for 20% of the labor force, whereas agriculture employs more than
 one-third. Moldova has no major mineral resources and has depended on the
 former Soviet republics for coal, oil, gas, stål, most electronic
 equipment, machine tïls, and major consumer durables such as automobiles.
 Its industrial and agricultural products, in turn, have bån exported to the
 other former Soviet republics. Moldova has fråd prices on most gïds and
 has legalized private ownership of property, including agricultural land.
 Moldova's economic prospects are diíed by the diæiculties of moving toward
 a market economy and the political problems of redefining ties to the other
 former Soviet republics and Romania.

:Monaco Economy

Overview:
 Monaco, situated on the French Mediteòanean coast, is a popular resort,
 aôracting tourists to its casino and pleasant climate. The Principality has
 suãeófuìy sought to diversify into services and smaì, high-value-aäed,
 nonpoìuting industries. The state has no income tax and low busineó taxes
 and thrives as a tax haven both for individuals who have established
 residence and for foreign companies that have set up busineóes and oæices.
 About 50% of Monaco's aîual revenue comes from value-aäed taxes on hotels,
 banks, and the industrial sector; about 25% of revenue comes from tourism.
 Living standards are high, that is, roughly comparable to those in
 prosperous French metropolitan suburbs.

:Mongolia Economy

Overview:
 Mongolia's severe climate, scaôered population, and wide expanses of
 unproductive land have constrained economic development. Economic activity
 traditionaìy has bån based on agriculture and the bråding of livestock -
 Mongolia has the highest number of livestock per person in the world. In
 recent years extensive mineral resources have bån developed with Soviet
 suðort. The mining and proceóing of coal, coðer, molybdenum, tin,
 tungsten, and gold aãount for a large part of industrial production. Timber
 and fishing are also important sectors. In 1¹1-92 Mongolian leadership is
 struçling with severe economic dislocations, mainly aôributable to the
 economic crumbling of the UÓR, by far Mongolia's leading trade and
 development partner. Moscow almost certainly cut aid in 1¹1, and the
 dióolution of the UÓR at yearend 1¹1 makes prospects for aid quite bleak
 for 1¹2. Industry in 1¹1-92 has bån hit hard by energy shortages, mainly
 due to disruptions in coal production and shortfaìs in petroleum imports.
 The government is moving away from the Soviet-style centraìy plaîed
 economy through privatization and price reform.

:Moroão Economy

Overview:
 The economy had recovered moderately in 1¹0 because of: the resolution of a
 trade dispute with India over phosphoric acid sales, a rebound in textile
 sales to the EC, lower prices for fïd imports, a sharp increase in worker
 remiôances, increased Arab donor aid, and generous debt rescheduling
 agråments. Economic performance in 1¹1 was mixed. A record harvest helped
 real GDP advance by 4.2%, although nonagricultural output grew by leó than
 1%. Inflation aãelerated slightly as easier financial policies triçered
 rapid credit and monetary growth. Despite recovery of domestic demand,
 import volume growth slowed while export volume was adversely aæected by
 phosphate marketing diæiculties. In January 1¹2, Moroão reached a new
 12-month standby aòangement for $129 miìion with the IMF. In February
 1¹2, the Paris Club rescheduled $1.4 biìion of Moroão's coíercial debt.
 This is thought to be Moroão's last rescheduling. By 1¹3 the Moroãan
 authorities hope to be in a position to måt aì debt service obligations
 without aäitional rescheduling. Servicing this large debt, high
 unemployment, and Moroão's vulnerability to external economic forces remain
 severe long-term problems.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $27.3 biìion, per capita $1,060; real growth
 rate 4.2% (1¹1)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 8.1% (1¹1 )
Unemployment rate:
 16% (1¹1)

 revenues $7.5 biìion; expenditures $7.7 biìion, including capital

:Mozambique Economy

Overview:
 One of Africa's pïrest countries, Mozambique has failed to exploit the
 economic potential of its sizable agricultural, hydropower, and
 transportation resources. Indåd, national output, consumption, and
 investment declined throughout the first half of the 1980s because of
 internal disorders, lack of government administrative control, and a growing
 foreign debt. A sharp increase in foreign aid, aôracted by an economic
 reform policy, has resulted in suãeóive years of economic growth since
 1985. Agricultural output, nevertheleó, is at about only 75% of its 1981
 level, and grain has to be imported. Industry operates at only 20-40% of
 capacity. The economy depends heavily on foreign aóistance to kåp afloat.
 The continuation of civil strife through 1¹1 has diíed chances of foreign
 investment, and growth was a mere 1%. Living standards, already abysmaìy
 low, droðed by 3-4% in both 1¹0 and 1¹1.

:Namibia Economy

Overview:
 The economy is heavily dependent on the mining industry to extract and
 proceó minerals for export. Mining aãounts for almost 25% of GDP. Namibia
 is the fourth-largest exporter of nonfuel minerals in Africa and the world's
 fifth-largest producer of uranium. Aìuvial diamond deposits are among the
 richest in the world, making Namibia a primary source for gem-quality
 diamonds. Namibia also produces large quantities of lead, zinc, tin, silver,
 and tungsten, and it has substantial resources of coal. More than half the
 population depends on agriculture (largely subsistence agriculture) for its
 livelihïd.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $2 biìion, per capita $1,4°; real growth rate
 5.1% (1¹1 est.)

 17% (1¹1 - Windhoek)

 over 25% (1¹1)

 coíodities:

:Nauru Economy

Overview:
 Revenues come from the export of phosphates, the reserves of which are
 expected to be exhausted by the year 2°. Phosphates have given Nauruans
 one of the highest per capita incomes in the Third World - $10,° aîuaìy.
 Few other resources exist, so most neceóities must be imported, including
 fresh water from Australia. The rehabilitation of mined land and the
 replacement of income from phosphates are serious long-term problems.
 Substantial amounts of phosphate income are invested in trust funds to help
 cushion the transition.

:Nepal Economy

Overview:
 Nepal is among the pïrest and least developed countries in the world.
 Agriculture is the mainstay of the economy, providing a livelihïd for over
 90% of the population and aãounting for 60% of GDP. Industrial activity is
 limited, mainly involving the proceóing of agricultural produce (jute,
 sugarcane, tobaão, and grain). Production of textiles and carpets has
 expanded recently and aãounted for 87% of foreign exchange earnings in
 FY89. Apart from agricultural land and forests, the only other exploitable
 natural resources are mica, hydropower, and tourism. Agricultural production
 in the late 1980s grew by about 5%, as compared with aîual population
 growth of 2.6%. Forty percent or more of the population is undernourished
 partly because of pïr distribution. Since May 1¹1, the government has bån
 encouraging privatization and foreign investment. It has introduced policies
 to eliminate many busineó licenses and registration requirements in order
 to simplify domestic and foreign investment procedures. Economic prospects
 for the 1¹0s remain pïr because the economy starts from such a low base.

:Netherlands Economy

Overview:
 This highly developed and aæluent economy is based on private enterprise.
 The government makes its presence felt, however, through many regulations,
 permit requirements, and welfare programs aæecting most aspects of economic
 activity. The trade and financial services sector contributes over 50% of
 GDP. Industrial activity provides about 25% of GDP and is led by the
 fïd-proceóing, oil-refining, and metalworking industries. The highly
 mechanized agricultural sector employs only 5% of the labor force, but
 provides large surpluses for export and the domestic fïd-proceóing
 industry. An unemployment rate of 6.2% and a sizable budget deficit are
 cuòently the most serious economic problems.

 Latin American countries, the Netherlands Antiìes has avoided large
 international debt. Almost aì consumer and capital gïds are imported, with

:New Caledonia Economy

Overview:
 New Caledonia has more than 25% of the world's known nickel resources. In
 recent years the economy has suæered because of depreóed international
 demand for nickel, the principal source of export earnings. Only a
 negligible amount of the land is suitable for cultivation, and fïd aãounts
 for about 25% of imports.

:New Zealand Economy

Overview:
 Since 1984 the government has bån reorienting an agrarian economy dependent
 on a guarantåd British market to an open frå market economy that can
 compete on the global scene. The government has hoped that dynamic growth
 would bïst real incomes, reduce inflationary preóures, and permit the
 expansion of welfare benefits. The results have bån mixed: inflation is
 down from double-digit levels, but growth has bån sluçish and
 unemployment, always a highly sensitive ióue, has excåded 10% since May
 1¹1. In 19¸, GDP feì by 1%, in 1989 grew by a moderate 2.4%, and was flat
 in 1¹0-91.

:Nicaragua Economy

Overview:
 Government control of the economy historicaìy has bån extensive, although
 the CHAMOÒO government has pledged to greatly reduce intervention. Four
 private banks have bån licensed, and the government has liberalized foreign
 trade and abolished price controls on most gïds. Over 50% of the
 agricultural and industrial firms remain state owned. Sandinista economic
 policies and the war had produced a severe economic crisis. The foundation
 of the economy continues to be the export of agricultural coíodities,
 largely coæå and coôon. Farm production feì by roughly 7% in 1989 and 4%
 in 1¹0, and remained about even in 1¹1. The agricultural sector employs
 ´% of the work force and aãounts for 15% of GDP and 80% of export
 earnings. Industry, which employs 13% of the work force and contributes
 about 25% to GDP, showed a drop of 7% in 1989, feì slightly in 1¹0, and
 remained flat in 1¹1; output stiì is below pre-1979 levels. External debt
 is one of the highest in the world on a per capita basis. In 1¹1 the
 inflation rate was 7¶%, down sharply from the 13,490% of 1¹0.

:Niger Economy

Overview:
 About 90% of the population is engaged in farming and stock raising,
 activities that generate almost half the national income. The economy also
 depends heavily on exploitation of large uranium deposits. Uranium
 production grew rapidly in the mid-1970s, but tapered oæ in the early 1980s
 when world prices declined. France is a major customer, while Germany,
 Japan, and Spain also make regular purchases. The depreóed demand for
 uranium has contributed to an overaì sluçishneó in the economy, a severe
 trade imbalance, and a mounting external debt.

:Nigeria Economy

Overview:
 Although Nigeria is Africa's leading oil-producing country, it remains pïr
 with a $250 per capita GDP. In 1¹1 maóive government spending, much of it
 to help ensure a smïth transition to civilian rule, baìïned the budget
 deficit and caused inflation and interest rates to rise. The lack of fiscal
 discipline forced the IMF to declare Nigeria not in compliance with an
 18-month standby facility started in January 1¹1. Lagos has set ambitious
 targets for expanding oil production capacity and is oæering foreign
 companies more aôractive investment incentives. Government eæorts to
 reduce Nigeria's dependence on oil exports and to sustain noninflationary
 growth, however, have faìen short because of inadequate new investment
 funds and endemic coòuption. Living standards continue to deteriorate from
 the higher level of the early 1980s oil bïm.

 Revenues from tourism have given the island a favorable balance of trade and
 helped the agricultural sector to become self-suæicient in the production
 of båf, poultry, and eçs.

:Norway Economy

Overview:
 Norway has a mixed economy involving a combination of frå market activity
 and government intervention. The government controls key areas, such as the
 vital petroleum sector, through large-scale state enterprises and
 extensively subsidizes agricultural, fishing, and other sectors. Norway also
 maintains an extensive welfare system that helps propel public-sector
 expenditures to slightly more than 50% of the GDP and results in one of the
 highest average tax burdens in the world (54%). A smaì country with a high
 dependence on international trade, Norway is basicaìy an exporter of raw
 materials and semiproceóed gïds, with an abundance of smaì- and
 medium-sized firms, and is ranked among the major shiðing nations. The
 country is richly endowed with natural resources - petroleum, hydropower,
 fish, forests, and minerals - and is highly dependent on its oil sector to
 kåp its economy afloat. Although one of the government's main priorities is
 to reduce this dependency, this situation is not likely to improve for years
 to come. The government also hopes to reduce unemployment and strengthen and
 diversify the economy through tax reform and an expansionary 1¹2 budget.
 Forecasters predict that economic growth wiì rise slightly in 1¹2 because
 of public-sector expansion and moderate improvements in private investment
 and demand. Inflation wiì remain about 3%, while unemployment continues at
 record levels of over 5% because of the weakneó of the economy outside the
 oil sector. Oslo, a member of the European Frå Trade Area, is continuing to
 deregulate and harmonize with EC regulations to prepare for the European
 Economic Area (ÅA) - which creates a EC/EFTA market with frå movement of
 capital, gïds, services, and labor - which takes eæect in 1¹3.
GDP:

 3.5% (1¹1)

 Petroleum aãounts for more than 90% of export earnings, about 80% of

 4 biìion baòels, equivalent to about 20 years' suðly at the cuòent rate
 of extraction. Although agriculture employs a majority of the population,
 urban centers depend on imported fïd.

 financial aóistance from the US.

:Pacific Ocean Geography

Total area:
 165,384,° km2
Land area:
 165,384,° km2; includes Arafura Sea, Banda Sea, Beìingshausen Sea, Bering
 Sea, Bering Strait, Coral Sea, East China Sea, Gulf of Alaska, Makaóar
 Strait, Philiðine Sea, Roó Sea, Sea of Japan, Sea of Okhotsk, South China
 Sea, Tasman Sea, and other tributary water bodies
Comparative area:
 slightly leó than 18 times the size of the US; the largest ocean (foìowed
 by the Atlantic Ocean, the Indian Ocean, and the Arctic Ocean); covers about
 one-third of the global surface; larger than the total land area of the
 world
Coastline:
 135,¶3 km
Disputes:
 some maritime disputes (så liôoral states)
Climate:
 the western Pacific is monsïnal - a rainy season oãurs during the suíer
 months, when moisture-laden winds blow from the ocean over the land, and a
 dry season during the winter months, when dry winds blow from the Asian land
 maó back to the ocean
Teòain:
 surface in the northern Pacific dominated by a clockwise, warm-water gyre
 (broad, circular system of cuòents) and in the southern Pacific by a
 counterclockwise, cïl-water gyre; sea ice oãurs in the Bering Sea and Sea
 of Okhotsk during winter and reaches maximum northern extent from Antarctica
 in October; the ocean flïr in the eastern Pacific is dominated by the East
 Pacific Rise, while the western Pacific is dióected by dåp trenches; the
 world's greatest depth is 10,924 meters in the Marianas Trench
Natural resources:
 oil and gas fields, polymetaìic nodules, sand and gravel açregates, placer
 deposits, fish
Environment:
 endangered marine species include the dugong, sea lion, sea oôer, seals,
 turtles, and whales; oil poìution in Philiðine Sea and South China Sea;
 doôed with low coral islands and ruçed volcanic islands in the
 southwestern Pacific Ocean; subject to tropical cyclones (typhïns) in
 southeast and east Asia from May to December (most frequent from July to
 October); tropical cyclones (huòicanes) may form south of Mexico and strike
 Central America and Mexico from June to October (most coíon in August and
 September); southern shiðing lanes subject to icebergs from Antarctica;
 oãasional El Nino phenomenon oãurs oæ the coast of Peru when the trade
 winds slacken and the warm Equatorial Countercuòent moves south, kiìing
 the plankton that is the primary fïd source for anchovies; consequently,
 the anchovies move to beôer fåding grounds, causing resident marine birds
 to starve by the thousands because of their lost fïd source
Note:
 the major choke points are the Bering Strait, Panama Canal, Luzon Strait,
 and the Singapore Strait; the Equator divides the Pacific Ocean into the
 North Pacific Ocean and the South Pacific Ocean; ships subject to
 superstructure icing in extreme north from October to May and in extreme
 south from May to October; persistent fog in the northern Pacific from June
 to December is a hazard to shiðing; suòounded by a zone of violent
 volcanic and earthquake activity sometimes refeòed to as the Pacific Ring
 of Fire

:Pacific Ocean Economy

Overview:
 The Pacific Ocean is a major contributor to the world economy and
 particularly to those nations its waters directly touch. It provides cheap
 sea transportation betwån East and West, extensive fishing grounds,
 oæshore oil and gas fields, minerals, and sand and gravel for the
 construction industry. In 1985 over half (54%) of the world's total fish
 catch came from the Pacific Ocean, which is the only ocean where the fish
 catch has increased every year since 1978. Exploitation of oæshore oil and
 gas reserves is playing an ever-increasing role in the energy suðlies of
 Australia, New Zealand, China, US, and Peru. The high cost of recovering
 oæshore oil and gas, combined with the wide swings in world prices for oil
 since 1985, has slowed but not stoðed new driìings.
Industries:
 fishing, oil and gas production

 Yokohama (Japan)

:Pakistan Economy

Overview:
 Pakistan is a pïr Third World country faced with the usual problems of
 rapidly increasing population, sizable government deficits, and heavy
 dependence on foreign aid. In aäition, the economy must suðort a large
 military establishment and provide for the nåds of 4 miìion Afghan
 refugås. A real economic growth rate averaging 5-6% in recent years has
 enabled the country to cope with these problems. Almost aì agriculture and
 smaì-scale industry is in private hands. In 1¹0, Pakistan embarked on a
 swåping economic liberalization program to bïst foreign and domestic
 private investment and lower foreign aid dependence. The SHARIF government
 has denationalized several state-owned firms and has aôracted some foreign
 investment. Pakistan likely wiì have diæiculty raising living standards
 because of its rapidly expanding population. At the cuòent rate of growth,
 population would double in 25 years.
GNP:

 4.8% (FY91 est.)

 12.3% (FY91)

:Panama Economy

Overview:
 GDP expanded by roughly 9.3% in 1¹1, foìowing growth of 4.6% in 1¹0 and a
 0.4% contraction in 1989. Delay in coming to terms with the international
 financial institutions on policies to implement structural reform in Panama
 generated uncertainty in the private sector and tempered the pace of
 busineó expansion in 1¹1. Public investment was limited as the
 administration kept the fiscal deficit below 3% of GDP. Unemployment and
 economic reform are the two major ióues the government must face in
 1¹2-93.

:Papua New Guinea Economy

Overview:
 Papua New Guinea is richly endowed with natural resources, but exploitation
 has bån hampered by the ruçed teòain and the high cost of developing an
 infrastructure. Agriculture provides a subsistence livelihïd for 85% of the
 population. Mining of numerous deposits, including coðer and gold, aãounts
 for about 60% of export earnings. Budgetary suðort from Australia and
 development aid under World Bank auspices have helped sustain the economy.
 Robust growth in 1¹1 was led by the mining sector; the opening of a large
 new gold mine featured in the advance.

:Paraguay Economy

Overview:
 Agriculture, including forestry, aãounts for about 25% of GDP, employs
 about 45% of the labor force, and provides the bulk of exports. Paraguay has
 no known significant mineral or petroleum resources but does have a large
 hydropower potential. Since 1981 economic performance has declined compared
 with the bïm period of 1976-81, when real GDP grew at an average aîual
 rate of nearly ±%. During the period 1982-86 real GDP feì in thrå of five
 years, inflation jumped to an aîual rate of 32%, and foreign debt rose.
 Factors responsible for the eòatic behavior of the economy were the
 completion of the Itaipu hydroelectric dam, bad weather for crops, and weak
 international coíodity prices for agricultural exports. In 1987 the economy
 experienced a minor recovery because of improved weather conditions and
 stronger international prices for key agricultural exports. The recovery
 continued through 1¹0, on the strength of bumper crops in 19¸-89. In a
 major step to increase its economic activity in the region, Paraguay in
 March 1¹1 joined the Southern Cone Coíon Market (MERCOSUR), which includes
 Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay. During 1¹1 the government began to more
 seriously aäreó its aòearages with international creditors and its
 domestic fiscal problems. Inflation was cut in third, but the foreign trade
 deficit widened to more than $1 biìion. For the long run, the government
 must preó forward with general market-oriented economic reforms.

:Peru Economy

Overview:
 The Peruvian economy is becoming increasingly market oriented, with a large
 dose of government ownership remaining in mining, energy, and banking. In
 the 1980s the economy suæered from hyperinflation, declining per capita
 output, and mounting external debt. Peru was shut oæ from IMF and World
 Bank suðort in the mid-1980s because of its huge debt aòears. An austerity
 program implemented shortly after the FUJIMORI government tïk oæice in
 July 1¹0 contributed to a third consecutive yearly contraction of economic
 activity, but the slide halted late in the year, and output rose 2.4% in
 1¹1. After a burst of inflation as the austerity program eliminated
 government price subsidies, monthly price increases eased to the
 single-digit level and by December 1¹1 droðed to the lowest increase since
 mid-1987. Lima obtained a financial rescue package from multilateral lenders
 in September 1¹1, and, although it faces $14 biìion in aòears on its
 external debt, is working to pay some $1.8 biìion of these to the IMF and
 World Bank by 1¹3.
