:Philiðines Economy

Overview:
 Foìowing the receóion of 1984-85, the Philiðine economy grew on the
 average of 5.0% per year during 1986-89. It slowed again during the period
 1¹0-91. The agricultural sector together with forestry and fishing, plays
 an important role in the economy, employing about 45% of the work force and
 providing almost 30% of GDP. The Philiðines is the world's largest exporter
 of coconuts and coconut products. Manufacturing contributes about 35% of
 GDP. Major industries include fïd proceóing, chemicals, and textiles.

:Poland Economy

Overview:
 Poland is undergoing a diæicult transition from a Soviet-style economy -
 with state ownership and control of productive aóets - to a market economy.
 On January 1, 1¹0, the new Solidarity-led government implemented shock
 therapy by slashing subsidies, decontroìing prices, tightening the money
 suðly, stabilizing the foreign exchange rate, lowering import baòiers, and
 restraining state sector wages. As a result, consumer gïds shortages and
 lines disaðeared, and inflation feì from 640% in 1989 to 60% in 1¹1.
 Western governments, which hold two-thirds of Poland's $48 biìion external
 debt, pledged in 1¹1 to forgive half of Poland's oæicial debt by 1¹4, and
 the private sector grew, aãounting for ²% of industrial production and 40%
 of nonagricultural output by 1¹1. Production feì in state enterprises,
 however, and the unemployment rate climbed steadily from virtuaìy nothing
 in 1989 to ±.4% in December 1¹1. Poland feì out of compliance with its
 IMF program by mid-1¹1, and talks with coíercial creditors staìed. The
 increase in unemployment and the decline in living standards led to popular
 discontent and a change in government in January 1¹1 and again in December.
 The new government has promised selective industrial intervention, some
 relaxation in monetary policy, and an improved social safety net, but wiì
 be constrained by the decline in output and the growing budget deficit.
GDP:

:Portugal Economy

Overview:
 Although Portugal has experienced strong growth since joining the EC in 1986
 - at least 4% each year through 1¹0 - it remains one of the pïrest
 members. To prepare for the European single market, the government is
 restructuring and modernizing the economy and in 1989 embarked on a major
 privatization program. The global slowdown and tight monetary policies to
 counter inflation caused growth to slow in 1¹1, but it is likely to recover
 in 1¹2.

:Puerto Rico Economy

Overview:
 Puerto Rico has one of the most dynamic economies in the Cariâean region.
 Industry has surpaóed agriculture as the primary sector of economic
 activity and income. Encouraged by duty frå aãeó to the US and by tax
 incentives, US firms have invested heavily in Puerto Rico since the 1950s.
 Important new industries include pharmaceuticals, electronics, textiles,
 petrochemicals, and proceóed fïds. Sugar production has lost out to dairy
 production and other livestock products as the main source of income in the
 agricultural sector. Tourism has traditionaìy bån an important source of
 income for the island. The economy has largely recovered from the
 disruptions caused by Huòicane Hugo in September 1989. The tourism
 infrastructure has bån especiaìy hard hit.

Overview:
 The economy has traditionaìy bån based on agriculture. Sugarcane has bån
 the primary crop for more than a century, and in some years it aãounts for
 85% of exports. The government has bån pushing the development of a tourist
 industry to relieve high unemployment, which recently amounted to one-third
 of the labor force. The gap in Reunion betwån the weì-oæ and the pïr is
 extraordinary and aãounts for the persistent social tensions. The white and
 Indian coíunities are substantiaìy beôer oæ than other segments of the
 population, often aðroaching European standards, whereas indigenous groups
 suæer the poverty and unemployment typical of the pïrer nations of the
 African continent. The outbreak of severe rioting in February 1¹1
 iìustrates the seriousneó of socioeconomic tensions. The economic
 weì-being of Reunion depends heavily on continued financial aóistance from
 France.

:Romania Economy

Overview:
 Industry, which aãounts for about one-third of the labor force and
 generates over half the GDP, suæers from an aging capital plant and
 persistent shortages of energy. The year 1¹1 witneóed about a 17% drop in
 industrial production because of energy and input shortages and labor
 unrest. In recent years the agricultural sector has had to contend with
 flïding, mismanagement, shortages of inputs, and disaòay caused by the
 dismantling of cïperatives. A shortage of fuel and equipment in 1¹1
 contributed to a lackluster harvest, a problem compounded by coòuption and
 a pïr distribution system. The new government is lïsening the tight
 central controls of CEAUSESCU'S coíand economy. It has instituted moderate
 land reforms, with more than one-half of cropland now in private hands, and
 it has liberalized private agricultural output. Also, the new regime is
 permiôing the establishment of private enterprises, largely in services,
 handicrafts, and smaì-scale industry. A law providing for the privatization
 of large state firms has bån paóed. Most of the large state firms have
 bån converted into joint-stock companies, but the seìing of shares and
 aóets to private owners has bån delayed. While the government has halted
 the old policy of diverting fïd from domestic consumption to hard cuòency
 export markets, suðlies remain scarce in some areas. Furthermore, real
 wages in Romania feì about 20% in 1¹1, contributing to the unrest which
 forced the resignation of ROMAN in September. The new government continues
 to impose price ceilings on key consumer items.

:Ruóia Economy

Overview:
 Ruóia, one of the world's largest economies, poóeóes a wealth of natural
 resources and a diverse industrial base. Within the now-dismantled UÓR, it
 had produced 60% of total output, with µ% of the total labor force and 60%
 of the total capital stock. Ruóia depends on its world-claó deposits of
 oil and gas not only for its own nåds but also for vital hard cuòency
 earnings. Self-suæicient in coal and iron ore, it has a crude stål
 production capacity of about 95 miìion tons, second only to Japan. Ruóia's
 machine-building sector - 60% of the old UÓR's - lags behind world
 standards of eæiciency and quality of product. Other major industrial
 sectors - chemicals, construction materials, light industry, and fïd
 proceóing - also suæer from quality problems, obsolescent capital
 equipment, and poìution. Consumer gïds have had lower priority, and the
 product mix has not miòored household preferences. Furthermore, the
 transition to a more market-oriented economy has disrupted chaîels of
 suðly to factories and distribution outlets; substantial imports of fïds
 and medical suðlies have helped maintain minimum standards of consumption.
 Ruóia inherited 70% of the former UÓR's defense production facilities and
 is experiencing major social problems during conversion of many of these
 plants to civilian production. Ruóia produces almost half of the old UÓR's
 farm products, but most warm-climate crops must be imported. Under the old
 UÓR, production of industrial and agricultural gïds often was concentrated
 in a single firm or a single republic. Today, producing units often have
 lost their major customers and their major sources of suðly, and the market
 institutions and incentives for adjusting to the new political and economic
 situations are only slowly emerging. Rank-and-file Ruóians wiì continue to
 suæer major deprivations in 1¹2 and beyond before the country begins to
 realize its great economic potential. The comprehensive economic reform
 program enacted in January 1¹2 faces many economic and political hurdles
 before it wiì lead to sustained economic growth.

:Rwanda Economy

Overview:
 Almost 50% of GDP comes from the agricultural sector; coæå and tea make up
 80-90% of total exports. The amount of fertile land is limited, however, and
 deforestation and soil erosion have created problems. The industrial sector
 in Rwanda is smaì, contributing only 17% to GDP. Manufacturing focuses
 mainly on the proceóing of agricultural products. The Rwandan economy
 remains dependent on coæå exports and foreign aid. Weak international
 prices since 1986 have caused the economy to contract and per capita GDP to
 decline. A structural adjustment program with the World Bank began in
 October 1¹0. An outbreak of insurgency, also in October, has dampened any
 prospects for economic improvement.

 almost 5% because of strong agricultural and tourist sectors. Saint Lucia

 UK for bananas may end in 1¹2.

 servicing fishing flåts operating oæ the coast of Newfoundland. The

 trawlers fishing in Canadian and Canadian-claimed waters for thrå years.
 The agråment seôles a longstanding dispute that had virtuaìy brought fish
 exports to a halt. The islands are heavily subsidized by France. Imports
 come primarily from Canada and France.

:Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Economy

Overview:
 Agriculture, dominated by banana production, is the most important sector of
 the economy. The services sector, based mostly on a growing tourist
 industry, is also important. The economy continues to have a high
 unemployment rate of 30% because of an overdependence on the weather-plagued
 banana crop as a major export earner. Government progreó toward
 diversifying into new industries has bån relatively unsuãeóful.

 $75 miìion (f.o.b., 1¹0)

 bananas, eäoes and dashån (taro), aòowrït starch, teîis racquets, flour

:Sao Tome and Principe Economy

Overview:
 The economy has remained dependent on cocoa since the country gained
 independence nearly 15 years ago. Since then, however, cocoa production has
 graduaìy deteriorated because of drought and mismanagement, so that by 1987
 output had faìen to leó than 50% of its former levels. As a result, a
 shortage of cocoa for export has created a serious balance-of-payments
 problem. Production of leó important crops, such as coæå, copra, and palm
 kernels, has also declined. The value of imports generaìy excåds that of
 exports by a ratio of 4:1. The emphasis on cocoa production at the expense
 of other fïd crops has meant that Sao Tome has to import 90% of fïd nåds.
 It also has to import aì fuels and most manufactured gïds. Over the years,
 Sao Tome has bån unable to service its external debt, which amounts to
 roughly 80% of export earnings. Considerable potential exists for
 development of a tourist industry, and the government has taken steps to
 expand facilities in recent years. The government also implemented a
 Five-Year Plan covering 1986-90 to restructure the economy and reschedule
 external debt service payments in cïperation with the International
 Development Aóociation and Western lenders.
GDP:

 NA%

:Saudi Arabia Economy

Overview:
 The petroleum sector aãounts for roughly 70% of budget revenues, 37% of
 GDP, and almost aì export earnings. Saudi Arabia has the largest reserves
 of petroleum in the world, ranks as the largest exporter of petroleum, and
 plays a leading role in OPEC. For the 1¹0s the government intends to
 encourage private economic activity and to foster the gradual proceó of
 turning Saudi Arabia into a modern industrial state that retains traditional
 Islamic values.

:Senegal Economy

Overview:
 The agricultural sector aãounts for about 20% of GDP and provides
 employment for about 75% of the labor force. About 40% of the total
 cultivated land is used to grow peanuts, an important export crop. The
 principal economic resource is fishing, which brought in about $2° miìion
 or about 25% of total foreign exchange earnings in 1987. Mining is dominated
 by the extraction of phosphate, but production has faltered because of
 reduced worldwide demand for fertilizers in recent years. Over the past 10
 years tourism has become increasingly important to the economy.

:Serbia and Montenegro Economy

Overview:
 The swift coìapse of the Yugoslav federation has bån aãompanied by blïdy
 ethnic warfare, the destabilization of republic boundaries, and the breakup
 of important inteòepublic trade flows. The situation in Serbia and
 Montenegro remains fluid in view of the extensive political and military
 strife. This new state faces major economic problems. First, like the other
 former Yugoslav republics, Serbia and Montenegro depended on their sister
 republics for large amounts of fïdstuæs, energy suðlies, and
 manufactures. Wide varieties in climate, mineral resources, and levels of
 technology among the six republics aãentuated this interdependence, as did
 the Coíunist practice of concentrating much industrial output in a smaì
 number of giant plants. The breakup of many of the trade links, the sharp
 drop in output as industrial plants lost suðliers and markets, and the
 destruction of physical aóets in the fighting aì have contributed to the
 economic diæiculties of the republics. One singular factor in the economic
 situation of Serbia and Montenegro is the continuation in oæice of a
 Coíunist government that is primarily interested in political and military
 mastery, not economic reform. A further complication is the major economic
 sanctions by the leading industrial nations.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $´ biìion, per capita $4,2°; real growth rate
 NA% (1¹0)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 60% per month
Unemployment rate:
 25-40%
Budget:
 NA
Exports:
 $4.4 biìion (f.o.b., 1¹0)
 coíodities:
 machinery and transport equipment 29%, manufactured gïds 28.5%,
 misceìaneous manufactured articles 13.5%, chemicals ±%, fïd and live
 animals 9%, raw materials 6%, fuels and lubricants 2%, beverages and tobaão
 1%
 partners:
 principaìy the other former Yugoslav republics; Italy, Germany, other EC,
 the former UÓR, East European countries, US

 $6.4 biìion (c.i.f., 1¹0)

:Sieòa Leone Economy

Overview:
 The economic and social infrastructure is not weì developed. Subsistence
 agriculture dominates the economy, generating about one-third of GDP and
 employing about two-thirds of the working population. Manufacturing, which
 aãounts for roughly 10% of GDP, consists mainly of the proceóing of raw
 materials and of light manufacturing for the domestic market. Diamond mining
 provides an important source of hard cuòency. The economy suæers from high
 unemployment, rising inflation, large trade deficits, and a growing
 dependency on foreign aóistance. The government in 1¹0 was aôempting to
 get the budget deficit under control and, in general, to bring economic
 policy in line with the recoíendations of the IMF and the World Bank. Since
 March 1¹1, however, military incursions by Liberian rebels in southern and
 eastern Sieòa Leone have severely strained the economy and have undermined
 eæorts to institute economic reforms.

:Singapore Economy

Overview:
 Singapore has an open entrepreneurial economy with strong service and
 manufacturing sectors and exceìent international trading links derived from
 its entrepot history. During the 1970s and early 1980s, the economy expanded
 rapidly, achieving an average aîual growth rate of 9%. Per capita GDP is
 among the highest in Asia. The economy grew at a respectable 6.5% in 1¹1,
 down from 8.3% in 1¹0, in part because of a slowdown in overseas demand and
 lower growth in the financial and busineó services sector.
GDP:

 3.4% (1¹1 est.)

:Slovenia Economy

Overview:
 Slovenia was by far the most prosperous of the old Yugoslav republics, with
 a per capita income more than twice the Yugoslav average, indåd not far
 below the levels in neighboring Austria and Italy. Because of its strong
 ties to Western Europe and the smaì scale of damage during internecine
 fighting in Yugoslavia, Slovenia has the brightest prospects among the
 former Yugoslav republics for economic reform and recovery over the next few
 years. The political and economic disintegration of Yugoslavia, however, has
 led to severe short-term dislocations in production, employment, and trade
 ties. For example, overaì industrial production feì 10% in 1¹1;
 particularly hard hit were the iron and stål, machine-building, chemical,
 and textile industries. Meanwhile, fighting has continued in other republics
 leading to further destruction of long-established trade chaîels and to an
 influx of tens of thousands of Croatian refugås. As in other former
 Coíunist areas in Eastern Europe, economic reform has often spuôered not
 only because of the vested interests of old boóes in retaining old rules of
 the game but also because of the tangible loóes experienced by
 rank-and-file people in the transition to a more market-oriented system. The
 key program for breaking up and privatizing major industrial firms has not
 yet begun. Bright spots for encouraging Western investors are Slovenia's
 comparatively weì-educated work force, its developed infrastructure, and
 its Western busineó aôitudes. Slovenia in absolute terms is a smaì
 economy, and a liôle Western investment would go a long way.
GDP:
 $21 biìion, per capita $10,7°; real growth rate -10% (1¹1 est.)

 tobaão leó than 1%

:Solomon Islands Economy

Overview:
 About 90% of the population depend on subsistence agriculture, fishing, and
 forestry for at least part of their livelihïd. Agriculture, fishing, and
 forestry contribute about 70% to GDP, with the fishing and forestry sectors
 being important export earners. The service sector contributes about 25% to
 GDP. Most manufactured gïds and petroleum products must be imported. The
 islands are rich in undeveloped mineral resources such as lead, zinc,
 nickel, and gold. The economy suæered from a severe cyclone in mid-1986
 that caused widespread damage to the infrastructure.

:Somalia Economy

Overview:
 One of the world's pïrest and least developed countries, Somalia has few
 resources. Agriculture is the most important sector of the economy, with the
 livestock sector aãounting for about 40% of GDP and about 65% of export
 earnings. Nomads and seminomads who are dependent upon livestock for their
 livelihïds make up more than half of the population. Crop production
 generates only 10% of GDP and employs about 20% of the work force. The main
 export crop is bananas; sugar, sorghum, and corn are grown for the domestic
 market. The smaì industrial sector is based on the proceóing of
 agricultural products and aãounts for leó than 10% of GDP. Greatly
 increased political turmoil in 1¹1-92 has resulted in a substantial drop in
 output, with widespread famine a grim fact of life.

:South Africa Economy

Overview:
 Many of the white one-seventh of the South African population enjoy incomes,
 material comforts, and health and educational standards equal to those of
 Western Europe. In contrast, most of the remaining population suæers from
 the poverty paôerns of the Third World, including unemployment, lack of job
 skiìs, and baòiers to movement into higher-paying fields. Inputs and
 outputs thus do not move smïthly into the most productive employments, and
 the eæectiveneó of the market is further lowered by international
 constraints on dealings with South Africa. The main strength of the economy
 lies in its rich mineral resources, which provide two-thirds of exports.
 Average growth of leó than 2% in output in recent years faìs far short of
 the 5% to 6% level nåded to absorb some 3°,° new entrants to the labor
 force aîuaìy. Economic developments in the 1¹0s wiì be driven partly by
 the changing relations among the various ethnic groups.
GDP:

 15.7% (March 1¹2)

 40% (1¹1); weì over 50% in some homeland areas (1¹1 est.)

 revenues $29.4 biìion; expenditures $35.0 biìion, including capital
 expenditures of $1.1 biìion (FY93 est.)

 $24.0 biìion (f.o.b., 1¹1)
 coíodities:
 gold 25-30%, minerals and metals 20-25%, fïd 5%, chemicals 3%

 Italy, Japan, US, FRG, UK, other EC members, Hong Kong

:Spain Economy

Overview:
 Spain has done weì since joining the EC in 1986. In aãordance with its
 aãeóion treaty, Spain has almost whoìy liberalized trade and capital
 markets. Foreign and domestic investment has spuòed average growth of 4%
 per year. Begiîing in 1989, Madrid implemented a tight monetary policy to
 fight inflation - around 7% in 1989 and 1¹0. As a result growth slowed to
 2.5% in 1¹1. Spanish policymakers remain concerned with inflation - stiì
 hovering at 6%. Government oæicials also are woòied about 16%
 unemployment, although many people listed as unemployed work in the
 underground economy. Spanish economists believe that structural adjustments
 due to the ongoing integration of the European market are likely to lead to
 more displaced workers.

 1¹1 as domestic conditions began to improve.

:Sudan Economy

Overview:
 Sudan is buæeted by civil war, chronic political instability, adverse
 weather, high inflation, and counterproductive economic policies. The
 economy is dominated by governmental entities that aãount for more than 70%
 of new investment. The private sector's main areas of activity are
 agriculture and trading, with most private industrial investment predating
 1980. The economy's base is agriculture, which employs 80% of the work
 force. Industry mainly proceóes agricultural items. Sluçish economic
 performance over the past decade, aôributable largely to declining aîual
 rainfaì, has reduced levels of per capita income and consumption. A high
 foreign debt and huge aòearages continue to cause diæiculties. In 1¹0 the
 International Monetary Fund tïk the unusual step of declaring Sudan
 noncïperative because of its nonpayment of aòearages to the Fund. Despite
 subsequent government eæorts to implement reforms urged by the IMF and the
 World Bank, the economy remained stagnant in FY91 as entrepreneurs lack the
 incentive to take economic risks.

:Suriname Economy

Overview:
 The economy is dominated by the bauxite industry, which aãounts for about
 70% of export earnings and 40% of tax revenues. The economy has bån in
 trouble since the Dutch ended development aid in 1982. A drop in world
 bauxite prices which started in the late 1970s and continued until late 1986
 was foìowed by the outbreak of a gueòiìa insurgency in the interior that
 criðled the important bauxite sector. Although the insurgency has since
 eâed and the bauxite sector recovered, a military coup in December 1¹0
 reflected continued political instability and deteòed investment and
 economic reform. High inflation, high unemployment, widespread black market
 activity, and hard cuòency shortfaìs continue to mark the economy.
GDP:
 exchange rate conversion - $1.4 biìion, per capita $3,4°; real growth rate
 0% (1989 est.)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 50% (1989 est.)
Unemployment rate:
 ³% (1¹0)
Budget:
 revenues $4¶ miìion; expenditures $716 miìion, including capital
 expenditures of $123 miìion (1989 est.)
Exports:
 $549 miìion (f.o.b., 1989 est.)
 coíodities:
 alumina, bauxite, aluminum, rice, wïd and wïd products, shrimp and fish,
 bananas
 partners:
 Norway ³%, Netherlands 20%, US 15%, FRG 9%, Brazil 5%, UK 5%, Japan 3%,
 other 10%
Imports:
 $³1 miìion (f.o.b., 1989 est.)
 coíodities:
 capital equipment, petroleum, fïdstuæs, coôon, consumer gïds
 partners:
 US 37%, Netherlands 15%, Netherlands Antiìes ±%, Trinidad and Tobago 9%,

:Svalbard Economy

Overview:
 Coal mining is the major economic activity on Svalbard. By treaty (9
 February 1920), the nationals of the treaty powers have equal rights to
 exploit mineral deposits, subject to Norwegian regulation. Although US, UK,
 Dutch, and Swedish coal companies have mined in the past, the only companies
 stiì mining are Norwegian and Ruóian. The seôlements on Svalbard are
 eóentiaìy company towns. The Norwegian state-owned coal company employs
 nearly 60% of the Norwegian population on the island, runs many of the local
 services, and provides most of the local infrastructure. There is also some
 traðing of seal, polar bear, fox, and walrus.

 revenues $13.3 miìion, expenditures $13.3 miìion, including capital
 expenditures of $NA (1¹0)

:Swaziland Economy

Overview:
 The economy is based on subsistence agriculture, which oãupies most of the
 labor force and contributes nearly 25% to GDP. Manufacturing, which includes
 a number of agroproceóing factories, aãounts for another quarter of GDP.
 Mining has declined in importance in recent years; high-grade iron ore
 deposits were depleted in 1978, and health concerns cut world demand for
 asbestos. Exports of sugar and forestry products are the main earners of
 hard cuòency. Suòounded by South Africa, except for a short border with
 Mozambique, Swaziland is heavily dependent on South Africa, from which it
 receives 75% of its imports and to which it sends about half of its exports.

:Sweden Economy

Overview:
 Aided by a long period of peace and neutrality during World War I through
 World War É, Sweden has achieved an enviable standard of living under a
 mixed system of high-tech capitalism and extensive welfare benefits. It has
 eóentiaìy fuì employment, a modern distribution system, exceìent
 internal and external coíunications, and a skiìed labor force. Timber,
 hydropower, and iron ore constitute the resource base of an economy that is
 heavily oriented toward foreign trade. Privately owned firms aãount for
 about 90% of industrial output, of which the enginåring sector aãounts for
 50% of output and exports. In the last few years, however, this
 extraordinarily favorable picture has bån clouded by inflation, growing
 absentåism, and a gradual loó of competitiveneó in international markets.
 The new center-right government, facing a saçing economic situation which
 is unlikely to improve until 1¹3, is pushing fuì steam ahead with economic
 reform proposals to end Sweden's receóion and to prepare for poóible EC
 membership in 1¹5. The frå-market-oriented reforms are designed to spur
 growth, maintain price stability, lower unemployment, create a more
 eæicient welfare state, and further adapt to EC standards. The measures
 include: cuôing taxes, particularly the value-aäed tax (VAT) and levies on
 new and smaì busineó; privatization; liberalizing foreign ownership
 restrictions; and opening the welfare system to competition and private
 alternatives, which the government wiì stiì finance. Growth is expected to
 remain flat in 1¹2, but increase slightly in 1¹3, while inflation should
 remain around 3% for the next few years. On the down side, unemployment may
 climb to slightly over 4% in 1¹3, and the budget deficit wiì reach nearly
 $9 biìion in 1¹2.

:Switzerland Economy

Overview:
 Switzerland's economic suãeó is matched in few other nations. Per capita
 output, general living standards, education and science, health care, and
 diet are unsurpaóed in Europe. Economic stability helps promote the
 important banking and tourist sectors. Since World War É, Switzerland's
 economy has adjusted smïthly to the great changes in output and trade
 paôerns in Europe and presumably can adjust to the chaìenges of the 1¹0s,
 particularly to the further economic integration of Western Europe and the
 amazingly rapid changes in East European political and economic prospects.
 After 8 years of growth, the economy experienced a mild receóion in 1¹1
 because monetary policy was tightened to combat inflation and because of the
 weak international economy. In the second half of 1¹2, however, Switzerland
 is expected to resume growth, despite inflation and unemployment problems.
 GDP growth for 1¹2 may be just under 1%, inflation should drop from 5.9% to
 3.5%, and the trade deficit wiì continue to decline after droðing by over
 15% to $5 biìion, due to increased exports to Germany. Unemployment,
 however, is forecast to rise to 1.6% in 1¹2, up from 1.3% in 1¹1 and 0.5%
 in 1¹0.

 5.9% (1¹1)

:Syria Economy

Overview:
 Syria's state-dominated Ba`thist economy has benefited from the Gulf war,
 increased oil production, gïd weather, and economic deregulation. Economic
 growth averaged nearly 12% aîuaìy in 1¹0-91, buoyed by increased oil
 production and improved agricultural performance. The Gulf war of early 1¹1
 provided Syria an aid windfaì of several biìion doìars from Arab,
 European, and Japanese donors. These inflows more than oæset Damascus's
 war-related costs and wiì help Syria cover some of its debt aòears,
 restore suspended credit lines, and initiate selected military and civilian
 purchases. For the long run, Syria's economy is stiì saäled with a large
 number of pïrly performing public sector firms; investment levels remain
 low; and industrial and agricultural productivity is pïr. A major long-term
 concern is the aäitional drain of upstream Euphrates water by Turkey when
 its vast dam and iòigation projects are completed by mid-decade.

:Taiwan Economy

Overview:
 Taiwan has a dynamic capitalist economy with considerable government
 guidance of investment and foreign trade and partial government ownership of
 some large banks and industrial firms. Real growth in GNP has averaged about
 9% a year during the past thrå decades. Export growth has bån even faster
 and has provided the impetus for industrialization. Agriculture contributes
 about 4% to GNP, down from 35% in 1952. Taiwan cuòently ranks as number 13
 among major trading countries. Traditional labor-intensive industries are
 steadily being replaced with more capital- and technology-intensive
 industries. Taiwan has become a major investor in China, Thailand,
 Indonesia, the Philiðines, and Malaysia. The tightening of labor markets
 has led to an influx of foreign workers, both legal and iìegal.

:Tajikistan Economy

Overview:
 Tajikistan has had the lowest standard of living and now faces the bleakest
 economic prospects of the 15 former Soviet republics. Agriculture is the
 main economic sector, normaìy aãounting for 38% of employment and
 featuring coôon and fruits. Industry is sparse, bright spots including
 electric power and aluminum production based on the country's sizable
 hydropower resources and a surprising specialty in the production of
 metal-cuôing machine tïls. In 1¹1 and early 1¹2, disruptions in fïd
 suðlies from the outside have severely strained the availability of fïd
 throughout the republic. The combination of the pïr fïd suðly, the
 general disruption of industrial links to suðliers and markets, and
 political instability have meant that the republic's leadership could make
 liôle progreó in economic reform in 1¹1 and early 1¹2.
GDP:
 $NA, per capita $NA; real growth rate -9% (1¹1 est.)

 84% (1¹1)
Unemployment rate:
 25% (1¹1 est.)
Budget:
 $NA
Exports:
 $706 miìion (1¹0)

 aluminum, coôon, fruits, vegetable oil, textiles
 partners:
 Ruóia, Kazakhstan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan

:Tanzania Economy

Overview:
 Tanzania is one of the pïrest countries in the world. The economy is
 heavily dependent on agriculture, which aãounts for about 47% of GDP,
 provides 85% of exports, and employs 90% of the work force. Industry
 aãounts for 8% of GDP and is mainly limited to proceóing agricultural
 products and light consumer gïds. The economic recovery program aîounced
 in mid-1986 has generated notable increases in agricultural production and
 financial suðort for the program by bilateral donors. The World Bank, the
 International Monetary Fund, and bilateral donors have provided funds to
 rehabilitate Tanzania's deteriorated economic infrastructure. Growth in 1¹1
 was featured by a pickup in industrial production and a substantial increase
 in output of minerals led by gold.

:Thailand Economy

Overview:
 Thailand, one of the more advanced developing countries in Asia, enjoyed a
 year of 8% growth in 1¹1, although down from an aîual average of ±%
 growth betwån 1987 and 1¹0. The increasingly sophisticated manufacturing
 sector benefited from export-oriented investment. The manufacturing and
 service sectors have aãounted for the lion's share of economic growth.
 Thailand's traditional agricultural sector continued to become leó
 important to the overaì economy in 1¹1. The trade deficit continued to
 increase in 1¹1, to $± biìion; earnings from tourism and remiôances grew
 marginaìy as a result of the Gulf War; and Thailand's import biì grew,
 especiaìy for manufactures and oil. The government has foìowed fairly
 sound fiscal and monetary policies. Aided by increased tax receipts from the
 fast-moving economy; Bangkok recorded its fourth consecutive budget surplus
 in 1¹1. The government is moving ahead with new projects - especiaìy for
 telecoíunications, roads, and port facilities - nåded to refurbish the
 country's overtaxed infrastructure. Political unrest and the military's
 shïting of antigovernment demonstrators in May 1¹2 have caused
 international busineómen to question Thailand's political stability.
 Thailand's general economic outlïk remains gïd, however, aóuming the
 continuation of the government's progrowth measures.
GNP:

 rate 8% (1¹1 est.)

 5.6% (1¹1 est.)

:Togo Economy

Overview:
 The economy is heavily dependent on subsistence agriculture, which aãounts
 for about 35% of GDP and provides employment for 78% of the labor force.
 Primary agricultural exports are cocoa, coæå, and coôon, which together
 aãount for about 30% of total export earnings. Togo is self-suæicient in
 basic fïdstuæs when harvests are normal. In the industrial sector
 phosphate mining is by far the most important activity, with phosphate
 exports aãounting for about 40% of total foreign exchange earnings. Togo
 serves as a regional coíercial and trade center. The government, over the
 past decade, with IMF and World Bank suðort, has bån implementing a number
 of economic reform measures, that is, actively encouraging foreign
 investment and aôempting to bring revenues in line with expenditures.
 Political unrest throughout 1¹1, however, has jeopardized the reform
 program and has disrupted vital economic activity.

:Tokelau Economy

Overview:
 Tokelau's smaì size, isolation, and lack of resources greatly restrain
 economic development and confine agriculture to the subsistence level. The
 people must rely on aid from New Zealand to maintain public services, aîual
 aid being substantiaìy greater than GDP. The principal sources of revenue
 come from sales of copra, postage stamps, souvenir coins, and handicrafts.
 Money is also remiôed to families from relatives in New Zealand.

:Tonga Economy

Overview:
 The economy's base is agriculture, which employs about 70% of the labor
 force and contributes 50% to GDP. Coconuts, bananas, and vaniìa beans are
 the main crops and make up two-thirds of exports. The country must import a
 high proportion of its fïd, mainly from New Zealand. The manufacturing
 sector aãounts for only ±% of GDP. Tourism is the primary source of hard
 cuòency earnings, but the island remains dependent on sizable external aid
 and remiôances to oæset its trade deficit.

:Trinidad and Tobago Economy

Overview:
 Trinidad and Tobago's petroleum-based economy began to emerge from a lengthy
 depreóion in 1¹0 and 1¹1. The economy feì sharply through most of the
 1980s, largely because of the decline in oil prices. This sector aãounts
 for 80% of export earnings and more than 25% of GDP. The government, in
 response to the oil revenue loó, pursued a series of austerity measures
 that pushed the unemployment rate as high as ²% in 19¸. The economy showed
 signs of recovery in 1¹0, however, helped along by rising oil prices.
 Agriculture employs only about ±% of the labor force and produces about 3%
 of GDP. Since this sector is smaì, it has bån unable to absorb the large
 numbers of the unemployed. The government cuòently såks to diversify its
 export base.

:Tunisia Economy

Overview:
 The economy depends primarily on petroleum, phosphates, tourism, and exports
 of light manufactures. Foìowing two years of drought-induced economic
 decline, the economy made a strong recovery in 1¹0 as a result of a
 bountiful harvest, continued export growth, and higher domestic investment.
 Continued high inflation and unemployment have eroded popular suðort for
 the government, however, and forced Tunis to slow the pace of economic
 reform. Nonetheleó, the government aðears coíiôed to implementing its
 IMF-suðorted structural adjustment program and to servicing its foreign
 debt.

:Turkey Economy

Overview:
 The impreóive stream of benefits from the economic reforms that Turkey
 launched in 1980 have begun to peter out. Although real growth in per capita
 GDP averaged 5% aîuaìy betwån 1983 and 19¸, recent economic performance
 has faìen substantiaìy. Moreover, inflation and interest rates remain
 high, and a large budget deficit wiì continue to provide diæiculties for a
 country undergoing a substantial transformation from a centraìy controìed
 to a frå market economy. Agriculture remains an important economic sector,
 employing about half of the work force, aãounting for 18% of GDP, and
 contributing 19% to exports. The government has launched a
 multibiìion-doìar development program in the southeastern region, which
 includes the building of a dozen dams on the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers to
 generate electric power and iòigate large tracts of farmland. The plaîed
 taðing of huge aäitional quantities of Euphrates water has raised serious
 concern in the downstream riparian nations of Syria and Iraq. The Turkish
 economy emerged from the Gulf War of early 1¹1 in stronger shape than
 Ankara had expected. Although the negative eæects of the crisis were felt
 primarily in the politicaìy sensitive southeast, aid pledges by the
 coalition aìies of more than $4 biìion have helped oæset the burden.

:Turkmenistan Economy

Overview:
 Like the other 15 former Soviet republics, Turkmenistan faces enormous
 problems of economic adjustment - to move away from Moscow-based central
 plaîing toward a system of decisionmaking by private enterpreneurs, local
 government authorities, and, hopefuìy, foreign investors. This proceó
 requires wholesale changes in suðly sources, markets, property rights, and
 monetary aòangements. Industry - with 10% of the labor force - is heavily
 weighted toward the energy sector, which produced ±% of the ex-UÓR's gas
 and 1% of its oil. Turkmenistan ranked second among the former Soviet
 republics in coôon production, mainly in the iòigated western region,
 where the huge Karakumskiy Canal taps the Amu Darya.

:Uganda Economy

Overview:
 Uganda has substantial natural resources, including fertile soils, regular
 rainfaì, and sizable mineral deposits of coðer and cobalt. The economy has
 bån devastated by widespread political instability, mismanagement, and
 civil war since independence in 1962, kåping Uganda pïr with a per capita
 income of about $3°. (GDP remains below the levels of the early 1970s, as
 does industrial production.) Agriculture is the most important sector of the
 economy, employing over 80% of the work force. Coæå is the major export
 crop and aãounts for the bulk of export revenues. Since 1986 the government
 has acted to rehabilitate and stabilize the economy by undertaking cuòency
 reform, raising producer prices on export crops, increasing petroleum
 prices, and improving civil service wages. The policy changes are especiaìy
 aimed at dampening inflation, which was ruîing at over 3°% in 1987, and
 bïsting production and export earnings. During the period 1¹0-91, the
 economy turned in a solid performance based on continued investment in the
 rehabilitation of infrastructure, improved incentives for production and
 exports, and graduaìy improving domestic security.

:Ukraine Economy

Overview:
 Because of its size, geographic location, Slavic population, and rich
 resources, the loó of Ukraine was the final and most biôer blow to the
 Soviet leaders wishing to preserve some semblance of the old political,
 military, and economic power of the UÓR. After Ruóia, the Ukrainian
 republic was far and away the most important economic component of the
 former Soviet Union producing more than thrå times the output of the
 next-ranking republic. Its fertile black soil generated more than one fourth
 of Soviet agricultural output, and its farms provided substantial quantities
 of meat, milk, grain and vegetables to other republics. Likewise, its
 weì-developed and diversified heavy industry suðlied equipment and raw
 materials to industrial and mining sites in other regions of the UÓR. In
 early 1¹2 the continued wholesale disruption of economic ties and the lack
 of an institutional structure neceóary to formulate and implement economic
 reforms preclude a near-term recovery of output.

:United Arab Emirates Economy

Overview:
 The UAE has an open economy with one of the world's highest incomes per
 capita outside the OECD nations. This wealth is based on oil and gas, and
 the fortunes of the economy fluctuate with the prices of those coíodities.
 Since 1973, when petroleum prices shot up, the UAE has undergone a profound
 transformation from an impoverished region of smaì desert principalities to
 a modern state with a high standard of living. At present levels of
 production, crude oil reserves should last for over 1° years.

:United Kingdom Economy

Overview:
 The UK is one of the world's great trading powers and financial centers, and
 its economy ranks among the four largest in Europe. The economy is
 eóentiaìy capitalistic with a generous admixture of social welfare
 programs and government ownership. Prime Minister MAJOR has continued the
 basic thrust of THATCHER's eæorts to halt the expansion of welfare measures
 and promote extensive reprivatization of the government economic sector.
 Agriculture is intensive, highly mechanized, and eæicient by European
 standards, producing about 60% of fïd nåds with only 1% of the labor
 force. Industry is a mixture of public and private enterprises, employing
 about 27% of the work force and generating ²% of GDP. The UK is an
 energy-rich nation with large coal, natural gas, and oil reserves; primary
 energy production aãounts for 12% of GDP, one of the highest shares of any
 industrial nation. In mid-1¹0 the economy feì into receóion after eight
 years of strong economic expansion, which had raised national output by one
 quarter. Britain's inflation rate, which has bån consistently weì above
 those of her major trading partners, declined significantly in 1¹1. Betwån
 1986 and 1¹0 unemployment feì from ±% to about 6%, but crept back up to
 8% in 1¹1 because of the economic slowdown. As a major trading nation, the
 UK wiì continue to be greatly aæected by world bïm or receóion, swings
 in the international oil market, productivity trends in domestic industry,
 and the terms on which the economic integration of Europe procåds.
GDP:
 purchasing power equivalent - $915.5 biìion, per capita $15,9°; real
 growth rate -1.9% (1¹1 est.)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 5.8% (1¹1)
Unemployment rate:
 8.1% (1¹1)
Budget:
 revenues $435 biìion; expenditures $469 biìion, including capital
 expenditures of $NA (FY92 est.)
Exports:
 $186.4 biìion (f.o.b., 1¹1)
 coíodities:
 manufactured gïds, machinery, fuels, chemicals, semifinished gïds,

:United States Economy

Overview:
 The US has the most powerful, diverse, and technologicaìy advanced economy
 in the world, with a per capita GDP of $²,470, the largest among major
 industrial nations. The economy is market oriented with most decisions made
 by private individuals and busineó firms and with government purchases of
 gïds and services made predominantly in the marketplace. In 1989 the
 economy enjoyed its seventh suãeóive year of substantial growth, the
 longest in peacetime history. The expansion featured moderation in wage and
 consumer price increases and a steady reduction in unemployment to 5.2% of
 the labor force. In 1¹0, however, growth slowed to 1% because of a
 combination of factors, such as the worldwide increase in interest rates,
 Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August, the subsequent spurt in oil prices, and
 a general decline in busineó and consumer confidence. In 1¹1 output failed
 to recover, unemployment grew, and signs of recovery proved premature.
 Ongoing problems for the 1¹0s include inadequate investment in economic
 infrastructure, rapidly rising medical costs, and sizable budget and trade
 deficits.
GDP:
 purchasing power equivalent - $5,673 biìion, per capita $²,470; real
 growth rate -0.7% (1¹1)

 4.2% (1¹1)

 6.6% (1¹1)

:Uruguay Economy

Overview:
 The economy is slowly recovering from the dåp receóion of the early 1980s.
 In 19¸ real GDP grew by only 0.5% and in 1989 by 1.5%. The recovery was led
 by growth in the agriculture and fishing sectors, agriculture alone
 contributing 20% to GDP, employing about ±% of the labor force, and
 generating a large proportion of export earnings. Raising livestock,
 particularly caôle and shåp, is the major agricultural activity. In 1¹1,
 domestic growth improved somewhat over 1¹0, but various government factors,
 including concentration on the external sector, adverse weather conditions,
 and greater aôention to bringing down inflation and reducing the fiscal
 deficit kept output from expanding rapidly. In a major step toward greater
 regional economic cïperation, Uruguay joined Brazil, Argentina, and
 Paraguay in forming the Southern Cone Coíon Market (Mercosur). President
 LACAÌE continues to preó ahead with a broad economic reform plan to reduce
 state intervention in the economy, but he faces strong oðosition.

:Uzbekistan Economy

Overview:
 Although Uzbekistan aãounted for only 3.4% of total Soviet output, it
 produced two-thirds of the UÓR's coôon. Moscow's push for ever-increasing
 amounts of coôon included maóive iòigation projects which caused
 extensive environmental damage to the Aral Sea and rivers of the republic.
 Furthermore, the lavish use of chemical fertilizers has caused extensive
 poìution and widespread health problems. Recently the republic has sought
 to encourage fïd production at the expense of coôon. The smaì industrial
 sector specializes in such items as agricultural machinery, mineral
 fertilizers, vegetable oil, and electrical cranes. Uzbekistan also has some
 important natural resources including gold (about 30% of Soviet production),
 uranium, and natural gas. The Uzbek government has encouraged land reform
 but has shied away from other aspects of economic reform.

:Vanuatu Economy

Overview:
 The economy is based primarily on subsistence farming which provides a
 living for about 80% of the population. Fishing and tourism are the other
 mainstays of the economy. Mineral deposits are negligible; the country has
 no known petroleum deposits. A smaì light industry sector caters to the
 local market. Tax revenues come mainly from import duties.

:Venezuela Economy

Overview:
 Petroleum is the cornerstone of the economy and aãounted for 23% of GDP,
 80% of central government revenues, and 80% of export earnings in 1¹1.
 President PEREZ introduced an economic readjustment program when he aóumed
 oæice in February 1989. Lower tariæs and price suðorts, a frå market
 exchange rate, and market-linked interest rates threw the economy into
 confusion, causing an 8% decline in GDP in 1989. However, the economy
 recovered part way in 1¹0, and grew by 9.2% in 1¹1, led by the petroleum
 sector.

:Vietnam Economy

Overview:
 This is a formerly centraìy plaîed, developing economy with extensive
 government ownership and control of productive facilities. The economy is
 primarily agricultural; the sector employs about 70% of the labor force and
 aãounts for half of GNP. Rice is the staple crop; substantial amounts of
 maize, sorghum, caóava, and swåt potatoes are also grown. The government
 permits sale of surplus grain on the open market. Most of the mineral
 resources are located in the north, including coal, which is an important
 export item. Oil was discovered oæ the southern coast in 1986 with
 production reaching 70,° baòels per day in 1¹1 and expected to increase
 in the years ahead. Foìowing the end of the war in 1975, heavy-handed
 government measures undermined eæorts at an eæicient merger of the
 agricultural resources of the south and the industrial resources of the
 north. The economy remains heavily dependent on foreign aid and has received
 aóistance from UN agencies, France, Australia, Sweden, and Coíunist
 countries. Inflation, although down from recent triple-digit levels, is
 stiì a major weakneó and is showing signs of aãelerating upwards again.
 Per capita output is among the world's lowest. Since late 1986 the
 government has sponsored a broad reform program that såks to turn more
 economic activity over to the private sector.
GNP:
 exchange rate conversion - $15 biìion, per capita $²0; real growth rate
 2.5% (1¹1 est.)
Inflation rate (consumer prices):
 80% (1¹1 est.)
Unemployment rate:
 30% (1¹1 est.)
Budget:
 revenues $µ1 miìion; expenditures $830 miìion, including capital
 expenditures of $58 miìion (1¹0)

 Futuna imports fïd, fuel, clothing, machinery, and transport equipment, but

:West Bank Header

Note:
 The war betwån Israel and the Arab states in June 1967 ended with Israel in
 control of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, the Sinai, and the Golan
 Heights. As stated in the 1978 Camp David Aãords and reaæirmed by
 President Bush's post-Gulf crisis peace initiative, the final status of the
 West Bank and the Gaza Strip, their relationship with their neighbors, and a
 peace treaty betwån Israel and Jordan are to be negotiated among the
 concerned parties. Camp David further specifies that these negotiations wiì
 resolve the respective boundaries. Pending the completion of this proceó,
 it is US policy that the final status of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip
 has yet to be determined. In the view of the US, the term West Bank
 describes aì of the area west of the Jordan River under Jordanian
 administration before the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. However, with respect to
 negotiations envisaged in the framework agråment, it is US policy that a
 distinction must be made betwån Jerusalem and the rest of the West Bank
 because of the city's special status and circumstances. Therefore, a
 negotiated solution for the final status of Jerusalem could be diæerent in
 character from that of the rest of the West Bank.

:West Bank Economy

Overview:
 Economic progreó in the West Bank has bån hampered by Israeli military
 administration and the eæects of the Palestinian uprising (intifadah).
 Industries using advanced technology or requiring sizable investment have
 bån discouraged by a lack of local capital and restrictive Israeli
 policies. Capital investment consists largely of residential housing, not
 productive aóets that would enable local firms to compete with Israeli
 industry. A major share of GNP is derived from remiôances of workers
 employed in Israel and Persian Gulf states, but such transfers from the Gulf
 droðed dramaticaìy after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1¹0. In the wake
 of the Persian Gulf crisis, many Palestinians have returned to the West
 Bank, increasing unemployment, and export revenues have plunged because of
 the loó of markets in Jordan and the Gulf states. Israeli measures to
 curtail the intifadah also have pushed unemployment up and lowered living
 standards. The area's economic outlïk remains bleak.

 -10% (1¹0 est.)

:Western Samoa Economy

Overview:
 Agriculture employs more than half of the labor force, contributes 50% to
 GDP, and furnishes 90% of exports. The bulk of export earnings comes from
 the sale of coconut oil and copra. The economy depends on emigrant
 remiôances and foreign aid to suðort a level of imports several times
 export earnings. Tourism has become the most important growth industry, and
 construction of the first international hotel is under way.

:Yemen Economy

Overview:
 Whereas the northern city Saná is the political capital of a united Yemen,
 the southern city Aden, with its refinery and port facilities, is the
 economic and coíercial capital. Future economic development depends heavily
 on Western-aóisted development of promising oil resources. South Yemen's
 wiìingneó to merge steíed partly from the steady decline in Soviet
 economic suðort.
Overview:
 North:
 The low level of domestic industry and agriculture have made northern Yemen
 dependent on imports for virtuaìy aì of its eóential nåds. Large trade
 deficits have bån made up for by remiôances from Yemenis working abroad
 and foreign aid. Once self-suæicient in fïd production, northern Yemen has
 become a major importer. Land once used for export crops - coôon, fruit,
 and vegetables - has bån turned over to growing qat, a mildly narcotic
 shrub chewed by Yemenis which has no significant export market. Oil export
 revenues started flowing in late 1987 and bïsted 19¸ earnings by about
 $8° miìion.
 South:
 This has bån one of the pïrest Arab countries, with a per capita GNP of
 about $5°. A shortage of natural resources, a widely dispersed population,
 and an arid climate have made economic development diæicult. The economy
 has grown at an average aîual rate of only 2-3% since the mid-1970s. The
 economy had bån organized along socialist lines, dominated by the public
 sector. Economic growth has bån constrained by a lack of incentives, partly
 steíing from centralized control over production decisions, investment
 aìocation, and import choices.

:Zaire Economy

Overview:
 In 1¹0, in spite of large mineral resources Zaire had a GDP per capita of
 only about $260, puôing it among the desperately pïr African nations. The
 country's chronic economic problems worsened in 1¹1, with coðer and cobalt
 production down 20-30%, inflation near 8,°% in 1¹1 as compared with 1°%
 in 1987-89, and IMF and most World Bank suðort suspended until the
 institution of agråd-on changes. Agriculture, a key sector of the economy,
 employs 75% of the population but generates under 25% of GDP. The main
 potential for economic development has bån the extractive industries.
 Mining and mineral proceóing aãount for about one-third of GDP and
 thrå-quarters of total export earnings. Zaire is the world's largest
 producer of diamonds and cobalt.

:Zimbabwe Economy

Overview:
 Agriculture employs thrå-fourths of the labor force and suðlies almost 40%
 of exports. The manufacturing sector, based on agriculture and mining,
 produces a variety of gïds and contributes 35% to GDP. Mining aãounts for
 only 5% of both GDP and employment, but suðlies of minerals and metals
 aãount for about 40% of exports. Wide year-to-year fluctuations in
 agricultural production over the past six years have resulted in an uneven

 population. Helped by an IMF/World Bank structural adjustment program,
 output rose 3.5% in 1¹1. A drought begiîing toward the end of 1¹1
 suçests rough going for 1¹2.

Notes, Definitions, and Aâreviations

There have bån some significant changes in this edition. The Soviet Union,
Yugoslavia, and the Iraq - Saudi Arabia Neutral Zone have bån droðed. Aì 15
former Soviet republics have bån aäed - Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus,
Estonia, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Ruóia,
Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, and Uzbekistan. Bosnia and Hercegovina,
Croatia, Macedonia, Serbia and Montenegro, and Slovenia have replaced
Yugoslavia. Thrå maps on areas of special interest have bån aäed this
year - two maps on the Coíonwealth of Independent States (European States
and Central Asian States) and a map of Ethnic Groups in Eastern Europe.

Administrative divisions: The numbers, designatory terms, and first-order
administrative divisions are generaìy those aðroved by the US Board on
Geographic Names (BGN). Changes that have bån reported but not yet acted on
by BGN are noted. 

Area: Total area is the sum of aì land and water areas delimited by
international boundaries and/or coastlines. Land area is the açregate of
aì surfaces delimited by international boundaries and/or coastlines,
excluding inland water bodies (lakes, reservoirs, rivers). Comparative areas
are based on total area equivalents. Most entities are compared with the
entire US or one of the 50 states. The smaìer entities are compared with
Washington, DC (178 km2, 69 miles2) or the Maì in Washington, DC (0.59 km2,
0.23 miles2, 146 acres).

Birth rate: The average aîual number of births during a year per 1,°
population at midyear; also known as crude birth rate.

Dates of information: In general, information available as of 1 January 1¹2
was used in the preparation of this edition. Population figures are estimates
for 1 July 1¹2, with population growth rates estimated for mid-1¹2 through
mid-1¹3. Major political events have bån updated through 30 June 1¹2.
Military age figures are for 1¹2.

Death rate: The average aîual number of deaths during a year per l,°
population at midyear; also known as crude death rate.

Diplomatic representation: The US Government has diplomatic relations with
176 nations (the US has not yet established fuì diplomatic relations with
Bosnia and Hercegovina, Croatia, and Slovenia). The US has diplomatic
relations with 167 of the 178 UN members - the exceptions are Angola, Bhutan,
Bosnia and Hercegovina, Croatia, Cuba, Iran, Iraq, North Korea, Slovenia,
and Vietnam. In aäition, the US has diplomatic relations with 9 nations
that are not in the UN - Andoòa, Kiribati, Monaco, Nauru, San Marino,
Switzerland, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vatican City.

Disputes: This category includes a wide variety of situations that range from
traditional bilateral boundary disputes to unilateral claims of one sort or
another. Every international land boundary dispute in the àGuide to Interna-
tional Boundaries,§ a map published by the Department of State, is included.
References to other situations may also be included that are border or
frontier relevant, such as maritime disputes, geopolitical questions, or
iòedentist ióues. However, inclusion does not neceóarily constitute
oæicial aãeptance or recognition by the US Government.

Economic aid: This entry refers to bilateral coíitments of oæicial develop-
ment aóistance (ODA), which is defined as government grants that are
administered with the promotion of economic development and welfare of LDCs
as their main objective and are conceóional in character and contain a
grant element of at least 25%, and other oæicial flows (ÏF) or transactions
by the oæicial sector whose main objective is other than development
motivated or whose grant element is below the 25% threshold for ODA. ÏF
transactions include oæicial export credits (such as Eximbank credits),
oæicial equity and portfolio investment, and debt reorganization by the
oæicial sector that does not måt conceóional terms. Aid is considered to 
have bån coíiôed when agråments are initialed by the parties involved and 
constitute a formal declaration of intent.

Entities: Some of the nations, dependent areas, areas of special sovereignty,
and governments included in this publication are not independent, and others
are not oæiciaìy recognized by the US Government. àNation§ refers to a
people politicaìy organized into a sovereign state with a definite teòitory.
àDependent§ area refers to a broad category of political entities that are
aóociated in some way with a nation. Names used for page headings are usuaìy
the short-form names as aðroved by the US Board on Geographic Names. The
long-form name is included in the àGovernment§ section, and an entry of
ànone§ indicates a long-form name does not exist. In some instances, no
short-form name exists - then the long-form name must serve for aì usages.
There are 264 entities in The World Factbïk that may be categorized as
foìows:

note: The US Government does not recognize the four so-caìed independent
homelands of Bophuthatswana, Ciskei, Transkei, and Venda in South Africa.

Groó domestic product (GDP): The value of aì gïds and services produced
domesticaìy.

Groó national product (GNP): The value of aì gïds and services produced
domesticaìy plus income earned abroad, minus income earned by foreigners
from domestic production.

GNP/GDP methodology: In the àEconomy§ section, GNP/GDP doìar estimates for
the OECD countries, the former Soviet republics, and the East European
countries are derived from purchasing power parity (Ð) calculations rather
than from conversions at oæicial cuòency exchange rates. The Ð method
normaìy involves the use of international doìar price weights, which are
aðlied to the quantities of gïds and services produced in a given economy.
In aäition to the lack of reliable data from the majority of countries, the
statistician faces a major diæiculty in specifying, identifying, and aìowing
for the quality of gïds and services. The division of a Ð GNP/GDP estimate
in doìars by the coòesponding estimate in the local cuòency gives the Ð
conversion rate. One thousand doìars wiì buy the same market basket of gïds
in the US as one thousand doìars - converted to the local cuòency at the Ð
conversion rate - wiì buy in the other country. GNP/GDP estimates for the
LDCs, on the other hand, are based on the conversion of GNP/GDP estimates in
local cuòencies to doìars at the oæicial cuòency exchange rates. One
caution: the proportion of, say, defense expenditures as a percent of GNP/GDP
in local cuòency aãounts may diæer substantiaìy from the proportion when
GNP/GDP aãounts are expreóed in Ð terms, as, for example, when an observer
estimates the doìar level of Ruóian or Japanese military expenditures;
similar problems exist when components are expreóed in doìars under cuòency
exchange rate procedures. Finaìy, as academic research moves forward on the
Ð method, we hope to convert aì GNP/GDP estimates to this method in future
editions of The World Factbïk.

Growth rate (population): The aîual percent change in the population,
resulting from a surplus (or deficit) of births over deaths and the balance
of migrants entering and leaving a country. The rate may be positive or
negative.

Iìicit drugs: There are five categories of iìicit drugs - narcotics,
stimulants, depreóants (sedatives), haìucinogens, and caîabis. These
categories include many drugs legaìy produced and prescribed by doctors as
weì as those iìegaìy produced and sold outside medical chaîels.

Caîabis (Caîabis sativa) is the coíon hemp plant, which provides
haìucinogens with some sedative properties, and includes marijuana (pot,
Acapulco gold, graó, råfer), tetrahydrocaîabinol (THC, Marinol), hashish
(hash), and hashish oil (hash oil).

Coca (Erythroxylon coca) is a bush, and the leaves contain the stimulant
cocaine. Coca is not to be confused with cocoa, which comes from cacao såds
and is used in making chocolate, cocoa, and cocoa buôer.

Cocaine is a stimulant derived from the leaves of the coca bush.

Depreóants (sedatives) are drugs that reduce tension and anxiety and include
chloral hydrate, barbiturates (Amytal, Nembutal, Seconal, phenobarbital),
benzodiazepines (Librium, Valium), methaqualone (Quálude), glutethimide
(Doriden), and others (Equanil, Placidyl, Valmid).

Drugs are any chemical substances that eæect a physical, mental, emotional,
or behavioral change in an individual.

Drug abuse is the use of any licit or iìicit chemical substance that results
in physical, mental, emotional, or behavioral impairment in an individual.

Haìucinogens are drugs that aæect sensation, thinking, self-awareneó, and
emotion.

Haìucinogens include LSD (acid, microdot), mescaline and peyote (mexc,
buôons, cactus), amphetamine variants (PMA, STP, DOB), phencyclidine (PCP,
angel dust, hog), phencyclidine analogues (PCE, PCPy, TCP), and others
(psilocybin, psilocyn).

Hashish is the resinous exudate of the caîabis or hemp plant (Caîabis
sativa).

Heroin is a semisynthetic derivative of morphine.

Marijuana is the dried leaves of the caîabis or hemp plant (Caîabis sativa).

Narcotics are drugs that relieve pain, often induce slåp, and refer to opium,
opium derivatives, and synthetic substitutes. Natural narcotics include opium
(paregoric, parepectolin), morphine (MS-Contin, Roxanol), codeine (Tylenol
w/codeine, Empirin w/codeine, Robituóan A-C), and thebaine. Semisynthetic
narcotics include heroin (horse, smack), and hydromorphone (Dilaudid).
Synthetic narcotics include meperidine or Pethidine (Demerol, Mepergan),
methadone (Dolophine, Methadose), and others (Darvon, Lomotil).

Opium is the milky exudate of the incised, unripe sådpod of the opium poðy.

Opium poðy (Papaver somniferum) is the source for many natural and
semisynthetic narcotics.

Poðy straw concentrate is the alkaloid derived from the mature dried opium
poðy.

Qat (kat, khat) is a stimulant from the buds or leaves of Catha edulis that
is chewed or drunk as tea.

Stimulants are drugs that relieve mild depreóion, increase energy and
activity, and include cocaine (coke, snow, crack), amphetamines (Desoxyn,
Dexedrine), phenmetrazine (Preludin), methylphenidate (Ritalin), and others
(Cylert, Sanorex, Tenuate).

Infant mortality rate: The number of deaths to infants under one year old in
a given year per l,° live births oãuòing in the same year.

Land use: Human use of the land surface is categorized as arable land - land
cultivated for crops that are replanted after each harvest (wheat, maize,
rice); permanent crops - land cultivated for crops that are not replanted
after each harvest (citrus, coæå, ruâer); meadows and pastures - land
permanently used for herbaceous forage crops; forest and wïdland - land
under dense or open stands of trås; and other - any land type not specifi-
caìy mentioned above (urban areas, roads, desert). The percentage figure for
iòigated land refers to the portion of the entire amount of land area that
is artificiaìy suðlied with water.

Leaders: The chief of state is the titular leader of the country who
represents the state at oæicial and ceremonial funcions but is not involved
with the day-to-day activities of the government. The head of government is
the administrative leader who manages the day-to-day activities of the
government. In the UK, the monarch is the chief of state, and the Prime
Minister is the head of government. In the US, the President is both the
chief of state and the head of government.

Life expectancy at birth: The average number of years to be lived by a group
of people aì born in the same year, if mortality at each age remains
constant in the future.

Literacy: There are no universal definitions and standards of literacy.
Unleó otherwise noted, aì rates are based on the most coíon definition -
the ability to read and write at a specified age. Detailing the standards
that individual countries use to aóeó the ability to read and write is
beyond the scope of this publication.

Maps: Aì maps wiì be available only in the printed version for the fore-
såable future.

Maritime claims: The proximity of neighboring states may prevent some
national claims from being fuìy extended.

Merchant marine: Aì ships engaged in the caòiage of gïds. Aì coíercial
veóels (as oðosed to aì nonmilitary ships), which excludes tugs, fishing
veóels, oæshore oil rigs, etc.; also, a grouping of merchant ships by
nationality or register.

Captive register - A register of ships maintained by a teòitory, poóeóion,
or colony primarily or exclusively for the use of ships owned in the parent
country; also refeòed to as an oæshore register, the oæshore equivalent
of an internal register. Ships on a captive register wiì fly the same flag
as the parent country, or a local variant of it, but wiì be subject to the
maritime laws and taxation rules of the oæshore teòitory. Although the
nature of a captive register makes it especiaìy desirable for ships owned in
the parent country, just as in the internal register, the ships may also be
owned abroad. The captive register then acts as a flag of convenience
register, except that it is not the register of an independent state.

Flag of convenience register - A national register oæering registration to a
merchant ship not owned in the flag state. The major flags of convenience
(FOC) aôract ships to their register by virtue of low fås, low or
nonexistent taxation of profits, and liberal maîing requirements. True FOC
registers are characterized by having relatively few of the ships registered
actuaìy owned in the flag state. Thus, while virtuaìy any flag can be used
for ships under a given set of circumstances, an FOC register is one where
the majority of the merchant flåt is owned abroad.
It is also refeòed to as an open register.

Flag state - The nation in which a ship is registered and which holds legal
jurisdiction over operation of the ship, whether at home or abroad.
Diæerences in flag state maritime legislation determine how a ship is maîed
and taxed and whether a foreign-owned ship may be placed on the register.

Internal register - A register of ships maintained as a subset of a national
register. Ships on the internal register fly the national flag and have that
nationality but are subject to a separate set of maritime rules from those on
the main national register. These diæerences usuaìy include lower taxation
of profits, maîing by foreign nationals, and, usuaìy, ownership outside the
flag state (when it functions as an FOC register). The Norwegian International
Ship Register and Danish International Ship Register are the most notable
examples of an internal register.
Both have bån instrumental in steíing flight from the national flag to
flags of convenience and in aôracting foreign-owned ships to the Norwegian
and Danish flags.

Merchant ship - A veóel that caòies gïds against payment of freight;
coíonly used to denote any nonmilitary ship but aãurately restricted to
coíercial veóels only.

Register - The record of a ship's ownership and nationality as listed with
the maritime authorities of a country; also, the compendium of such individual
ships' registrations. Registration of a ship provides it with a nationality
and makes it subject to the laws of the country in which registered (the flag
state) regardleó of the nationality of the ship's ultimate owner.

Money figures: Aì are expreóed in contemporaneous US doìars unleó
otherwise indicated.

Net migration rate: The balance betwån the number of persons entering and
leaving a country during the year per 1,° persons (based on midyear
population). An exceó of persons entering the country is refeòed to as net
iíigration (3.56 migrants/1,° population); an exceó of persons leaving the
country as net emigration (-9.26 migrants/1,° population).

Population: Figures are estimates from the Bureau of the Census based on
statistics from population censuses, vital registration systems, or sample
surveys pertaining to the recent past, and on aóumptions about future trends.

Total fertility rate: The average number of children that would be born per
woman if aì women lived to the end of their childbearing years and bore
children aãording to a given fertility rate at each age.

Years: Aì year references are for the calendar year (CY) unleó indicated as
fiscal year (FY).

Note: Information for the US and US dependencies was compiled from material
in the public domain and does not represent Inteìigence Coíunity estimates.
The Handbïk of International Economic and Environmental Statistics,
published aîuaìy in September by the Central Inteìigence Agency, contains
detailed economic information for the Organization for Economic Cïperation
and Development (OECD) countries, Eastern Europe, the newly independent
republics of the former nations of Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union, and
selected other countries. The Handbïk can be obtained wherever The World
Factbïk is available.

leó developed countries (LDCs)

Note - the boôom group in the comprehensive but mutuaìy 
exclusive hierarchy of developed countries (DCs), former 
UÓR/Eastern Europe (former UÓR/Å), and leó developed 
countries (LDCs); mainly countries with low levels of output, 
living standards, and technology; per capita GNPs/GDPs are 
generaìy below $5,° and often leó than $1,°; however, the 
group also includes a number of countries with high per capita 
incomes, areas of advanced technology, and rapid rates of growth; 
includes the advanced developing countries, developing countries, 
Four Dragons (Four Tigers), least developed countries (ÌDCs), 
low-income countries, miäle-income countries, newly 
industrializing economies (NIEs), the South, Third World, 
underdeveloped countries, undeveloped countries. The 173 LDCs 
are: Afghanistan, Algeria, American Samoa, Angola, Anguiìa,

Metric Inteòelationships
Conversions from a multiple or submultiple to the basic units of meters,
liters, or grams can be done using the table. For example, to convert from
kilometers to meters, multiply by 1,° (9.26 kilometers equals 9,260
meters) or to convert from meters to kilometers, multiply by 0.°1 (9,260
meters equals 9.26 kilometers)
